review_text: So i use Facebook messenger and whats up app a lot(daily) so this is an amazing devise for me. It is so cool, it moves when you move (moderate speed, so don't run) and it zooms in and out (for example if you were in a room talking and someone else comes in it zooms out to catch that person and vise versa when that person leaves it zooms back in on you). Also if there is a sound in the background it concentrates on your voice so the person on the other line does not get distracted. Also on messenger you can tell stories (kids stories). Now for Alexa app, its good but not perfect let me explain more so it does pull up recipes and turns on and off the lights but it doesn't save the recipe like the other Alexa apps and it doesn't show you the feed to your cameras but other than that its great and very useful to not have you holding your phone all the time and can multi task while you're chatting... i love it. My advice to you if you dont use the messenger and whats up apps regularly it wouldn't be useful to you. Hope this review helps your decision.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: Not many people have mentioned Whatsapp calling via Portal so I'll focus on that. You link your Whatsapp account from your phone via the Whatsapp Web feature and it takes about a minute. You can then choose to add some of your Whatsapp friends/family to your Favorites so that they're on your home screen. You can also choose some of your Facebook friends as Favorites. This blends in your Favorites from both apps so that you don't have switch between the apps or even think about who uses what app. I think this is very useful and makes it much easier for anyone to use Portal. Your recent contacts also show up on the top of the home screen. The Smart Camera really is great and will amaze you with just how much better it makes video calls. The way it slowly zooms in to focus on you and anyone else in front of it is a lot of fun. You can stand up, walk around, or sit and just talk without thinking about looking at the camera. Currently, the Portal supports Facebook group calls with 8 people and Whatsapp calls with 4 if you call from the Portal BUT up to 8 if you're just getting an incoming group video call. (I checked with their support to make sure.) Zoom will support Portal at some later 2020 date. And for the times when you want to just make an audio only call, this works like a great speaker phone thanks to the advanced mics. Note that you currently can't talk to Portal to make an audio only call. (If you tap on a contact you always get the audio only or video call options.) There's a handful of apps but the most useful ones for most people are probably Spotify and Pandora for music. The speaker is in the back but it's surprisingly good and quite loud. You can ask "Hey Portal, play The Beatles" just like you would with a Google Nest Home or Amazon Echo. You can also use the CBS News and ABC News apps which are useful and just convenient. I can't comment on Facebook Video apps as I have no idea who watches anything on it. Is it the perfect well-rounded device? No. It has a few apps and Alexa integration so while it can set alarms, timers, and control your smart lights, it is probably not the best device for it. It's a little slow and all of that seems secondary. Is it nearly perfect for video calling on Facebook and Whatsapp? Yes. Especially for our older relatives that aren't always looking at their phones. This is the video phone from all those old movies and maybe that's all you need.
review_header: Whatsapp and Facebook Messenger calls like never before

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: I bought this for my mother and step father, so that my kids can keep in touch with them. The whole idea has been nothing short of spectacular. Only complaint is the need for a facebook account, but really worth it if you live a long distance from family. My daughter spends a lot of time baking with her grandma (Wyoming) and aunt (Nevada) who also bake the same items at their house. It's hard to imagine a more immersive experience with your relatives without actually being together. We have the smaller version and I sent my sister the same smaller version; they all work great! Privacy wise, we just unplug it when not in use, no issues.
review_header: Bought for kids to keep in touch with grandparents, excellent!

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: Initially I did not want to trust anything with "Facebook" on it, but after watching the video and seeing they have a PHYSICAL sliding switch to cover up the camera (and the promise that it also shuts off the microphone connection), I thought I might be able to trust it a bit. My previous experience with Alexa has been limited to the phone app, and a toy robot (Vector) that has Alexa integration. My overall impression is that this is a nice device for playing music, displaying photos, and interacting with Alexa, but not much else. The device is professionally packaged like higher end phones or tablets from other manufacturers. Initial setup is simple. You power on the device, connect to WiFi, do a firmware update that takes about 15 minutes, restart the device, then login to Facebook and Amazon. The device responds to two commands: "Hey ..." or "Alexa". Depending on which wake up greeting you speak, you'll either get Facebook or Amazon to respond. I have Amazon Prime, so the biggest feature I use the device for is playing Amazon Prime music by asking Alexa to play what I want. Amazon Prime music is nice, as it typically displays the lyrics and has a huge variety of music. I think the speaker has great volume and sound. It has a good sized speaker on the back of the device, so you get good sound that bounces off the walls back towards you. Volume controls are easily accessible on the side of the frame. The Portal can also connect to iHeartRadio, Pandora, and Spotify to play other music or podcasts. (The bass is actually quite impressive for such a small device!) I also use the Portal to display photos from Facebook. You can select which photos you want it to display from albums, or your latest photos. If you install the Portal app on your phone, you can also add individual photos to show on your Portal device. I've tested a few video calls, but I don't frequently video chat with people. The sound was nice, and didn't capture an echo from the speaker like some other video chat programs do. The camera does follow you, but it moves very slowly. I have the Portal on my desk, and with the angle it was at, it often had the ceiling lights in the frame, causing me to move to one side to prevent too much light from being on the call. Pros: 1. Very good music playing device, with a large library of songs from Amazon, and others. 2. There is a cover that slides over the video camera, and when pushed further disables the microphone for privacy. 3. Displaying photos on the device is nice Cons: 1. There are very limited apps for the device. I'd expect it to come with a Facebook app or Amazon apps such as Amazon Music. You can login to Facebook via the browser, and you can control music with Alexa, but I'd expect these to be apps. You can also access YouTube via the browser, and they provide a shortcut for that, but again, not an app. There is also no built in weather app. You can display the current weather in your area on the main screen, but you can't see a forecast unless you ask Alexa to display the forecast. 2. The phone app currently has very limited functionality for loading photos, or calling your Portal device, or other contacts. No other functionality. 3. There is no cast capability for displaying content (music, photos, videos) from one device onto the Portal. A friend of mine has an Echo Show (or whatever the little round one is with the small screen) and I think it may be better (though a smaller screen).
review_header: Good sound and screen. Limited use.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: The screen is gorgeous. And you can talk to it as if it's Alexa ... though it doesn't seem to be able to play Prime Video the way Alexa can. Asking anything by starting with "Hey Portal" is bound to lead to disappointment. This is the most immature AI that I've encountered in a long time. It feels like a contest entry rather than like a product that has actually shipped. But, so what, it's got Alexa. And the video calling works. And it can show your facebook photos. And the screen is gorgeous. It's like that friend who isn't very bright and isn't a good conversationalist, but is good looking, strong, and well-connected. So... don't have high hopes for "hey portal." Get it because you're an early adopter, or gadget-lover and because you're willing to lower your expectations in the short term. I honestly do have high hopes for this product in the long run, even though it's a bit embarrassing (or admirably bold in putting itself out there without being perfect?) in the first version. And since the problems are software/AI, I think there are few downsides to buying this now and watching the software evolve. The screen is gorgeous, and, at worst, it will be the best digital picture frame / video phone that is synced to your facebook account and can also play amazon music ... that you've ever owned. I really like the Portal, but I feel a sort of maternal need to pat it on the back and tell it to not give up despite its current challenges. Facebook Portal can be a dark horse. It's hard being such a late entrant to the game when people are used to Alexa and Google Home. But it stands apart because of it's superior screen/hardware and its integration with your facebook photos and contacts. That makes up for a lot. Manage your expectations --- expect the AI to be subpar - but the features and integrations to be awesome - and you'll be happy! My overall vote is that Facebook portal is definitely worth buying - but only second to an existing setup with Alexa or Google Home. It definitely can't compete as your primary in-home AI. Not yet. But it's worth adding on, if you can afford to. Could be a real solid contender by 2020.
review_header: Buggy AI in first version - but lots of promise, and great integrations/hardware

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: This is some really bad software. On the good side, the Portal TV is a super handy way to video chat using your TV... once you finally get to the calling part. Unfortunately, the set-up process and user interface almost makes it not even worth it. Paired with the fact that Facebook locks you into their little messenger world... is not ideal. When I turned the device on for the first time, it needed a 40 minute software download. (I have descent broadband). Then it started to install, but I accidentally touched the back button on the remote, and it had to download the software update again, for another 40 minutes. All-in-all, device set-up took me 2 hours. Unacceptable. The user interface is clunky. Keep finding little glitchy things throughout that are frustrating. Searching contacts is hard, unless they are in your 'favorites' (which of course big brother facebook picks for you). The alexa integration doesn't add much, but it is nice to say "Hey Portal, call John Doe". There are cool features like games and mic drop and facebook watch, but they dont work unless the other side also has the same device, which nobody does. I have also found that not many people answer fb messenger calls, when you try and call. You have to text them first and let them know. For group calls, you cant schedule like a zoom and send a link. You have to create a room (which is super clunky) and hope people see it (which they dont). I read that it supports Zoom, but I dont see it in the available apps. The actual video call is pretty cool, since the camera pans and zooms auto-magically. Its very intelligent with its movements, even with multiple people moving around. But everybody I call is using their phone, and are in portrait mode (not landscape) and are moving around (cause... its a phone). I had envisioned more of a video conferencing feel like in the office on a big screen. But since it only works with messenger, which everyone has on their phone, its not a great experience. Dont recommend. Just too clunky and the software is disappointing for such a prominent company. The interface is like a prototype that a college coding class would make, with illegible fonts and oversimplified menus. Sad really. The exception would be if you plan to have frequent calls with someone else with a Portal, and you could suffer through the excruciating set-up and learning the clunky interface so you could just say "Hey Portal, call Jane Doe" when you want to use it. Then it might be OK.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: This is a really nice device. It works pretty good but for my needs has just a couple of flaws. Video Calling - The video calling on this thing is where it stands out for sure. I have used Nest home devices and alexa devices and the technology that this has blows it all out of the water. Picture quality is great. It is nice that it adjusts as you move around. You can even add little filters to it while you talk which the kids love love love. My one complaint with this is that you have to use either Facebook Messenger or WhatsApp. I wish there were more options and I wish you could communicate directly with other Alexa enabled devices. However, if you use Messenger or WhatsApp it is awesome. Alexa integration - The Alexa integration is pretty good but does have a couple of flaws. It can not communicate directly with other Alexa enabled devices which was a bummer as we have multiple devices throughout the house and like to use them to drop in and communicate which can not be done with this. Music - Sound quality is pretty good. One issue we had is that when it was playing pandora it would randomly just turn off the music after 15 or so minutes and we would have to ask it to start playing again. Kind of annoying and not sure what would cause it to happen but it happened all the time. Ring Integration - Worked flawlessly with our Ring doorbell. Which was awesome with the big screen that this device had. Apps - There are quite a few more apps available for this device then say an Amazon device. That was nice. Had Youtube and others built right in which was convenient for sure. Overall, these things are pretty awesome. We have enjoyed ours and it was well built. If it integrated with more methods of video calling and with other Alexa devices it would be a complete slam dunk in our household.
review_header: Pretty solid device with a few things I wish you could change

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black

Eventually in about 10 seconds, it will start the reset process and then you can remove your hand from the side button. Wanted to create a simple anon account to use it and got stuck in facebook review process, asking for photograph, mobile number etc! Not sure if I will keep this. Too hard to setup, no drop-in feature yet. Good idea, but bad execution, bad testing.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: The Facebook Portal Plus is pretty cool, and the screen is humongous compared to the Echo Show. But the Echo still has more features than the Portal. So how you feel about it I think will depend on what features you‚Äôre looking for. The large screen of the Portal is an outstanding choice for those with limited vision. Small screens make seeing anything quite difficult for some, like parents and grandparents. So in this instance the Portal Plus is a far better choice than the Echo Show. What‚Äôs the point in video calls if you can‚Äôt even see the person on the other side? However for the tech types who like to have everything in their home integrated (turning on light, locking doors, controlling the thermostat, etc), or for those who enjoy the added features of the Alexa virtual assistant, the Echo Show has all that and more. But with a smaller screen. For myself, it‚Äôs hard to pick a favorite. The Portal is being updated with new features and if they continue to do so, it could be a real rival for the Echo Show. Especially with the huge screen. However Amazon could easily counter this by making a larger Echo Show of their own. As of right now, I have both. The Echo Show gets the most use. But if I struggled with seeing things on smaller screens, the Portal Plus would be the number one device I‚Äôd turn to.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black

review_text: Well - i mean, it's Facebook Portal - does what it is supposed to do, offer video calling without having to hold your phone; and is a good item to have on the desk. I have a lot of remote family, so this comes in handy........with all that said: It's slow. The touch screen doesn't often respond. The initial update took almost an hour on a 1GB connection. Switching between apps is very slow. There is not a lot of apps you can dd to this. Doesn't support Apple Music, which most people have these days and only supports Spotify, iHeart Radio and Pandora..............with the exception of Spotify, most of the others are just not that useful. Story time is a nice feature, kids love it. But, the slowness.......man, the slowness bites. Still, it does what it is supposed to do, so i guess a good buy.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: I really wanted to love this, but the cons outweigh the pros. I bought this as a present for my mom to video chat with grandkids using Facebook messenger. -The device is very bulky, much thicker than I expected. -Too confusing to use "Hey Portal" and "Hey Alexa" on one device. Alexa cannot answer or make calls, only Portal can by saying "Hey Portal." I kept accidentally saying, "Hey Alexa", to make a call and it kept telling me that voice commands would not work on that device. -I tested a few calls, and depending on the other person's messenger app, sometimes it would call to the portal and sometimes it would only call to my phone. It also calls both at the same time. -You cannot use the portal voice command to call with WhatsApp, only Facebook messenger. -My device did not have a setting for using the device GPS to know when you are home, to route the calls to your phone instead when you are not at home. That was very confusing. I also did not see the option to switch the call from the portal to my phone during video chat. -The camera moving around and zooming in and out was pretty cool, but it also did think my Christmas tree was a person and it kept zooming in to keep both of us in the frame lol. Overall, it is too glitchy and not advanced enough for the price, in my opinion. Especially just for video chat since I can't see her using it for anything else.
review_header: Too expensive for basically just video calls.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: It handles it's primary function of video calls OK enough. The way the camera tracts people within it's field's range is pretty cool. And it's nice that now I have a large screen to see our grandchildren, but at times it seems a bit grainy compared to the first generation smaller portal I used to have. Also, I miss the touch screen capabilities of the original portal for doing things like selecting a subject to stay focused on. The available applications seems to be very limited as well. I could swear the 1st gen had a lot more apps to choose from. I do watch Amazon Prime through it, which so far works flawlessly, but it would be nice to have a browser, maybe utube.. or come on, this is a facebook product so how about facebook on it? I do have to admit that story time is a lot of fun with the youngest in our family. :) Alexa is OK on this.. handles my home automation OK enough, and MUCH clearer audio than my 3rd gen Echo Dot, but is a bit cumbersome in some aspects. If I want to see my Ring Doorbell video I can't just say to show me the front door. First I have to say "hey portal, show me the home page." This changes the HDMI port to the correct one for portal, as well as turn on the TV if its off. Once I have the portal screen showing then I can say "Alexa, show me the front door." and by that time I've already walked to the front door to see who's there. If I just tell Alexa to show me the front door it'll say OK, but nothing happens until I activate portal first. Frustrating. The HDMI-CEC control is also interesting. Yes, it will turn on my TV while switching to the portal port.. however; I can't use it to switch back to my cable-box's HDMI, control volume or turn the TV off. Perhaps there are commands to do this, but I haven't found them yet.

She has been able to talk to both of her sons and each grandchild and great grandkids. The touch screen set up made it so easy for her to call me and for her to use. The nurse told me that she used it so often she was ‚Äúgoing to wear it out‚Äù. I am forever grateful for the portal +. It has been a blessing.

review_text: The headline says it all. 1. There is no single video conferencing tool. Especially no Zoom. IMO, Group video calls are not the same as I can't control who can be on video/not and mute/unmute. 2. Facebook Workplace Live is just one blank screen and I am not even sure how to resolve it. NOT worth 150$.
review_header: Portal TV doesn't have ZOOM and any other video conferencing software

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: We got these for Christmas. You have to have a Messenger / Facebook account to use it. You can easily video call another messenger account or use WhatsApp. Picture is very clear and you can have multiple people on at one time. Great for seeing the kids and grandkids when they live in another state. You also have a browser on it so you can surf the internet with it and add bookmarks / apps as needed. It has story time on it and the grandkids loved it. As it tells the story they are actually in the story, this is done by using the camera. They had a blast with it. I had a blast watching them laugh and point at themselves in the story book. Great memories. As for privacy when you are finished with the video chatting, just slide the camera and microphone switch to off. A plastic cover will hide the camera. You can still use all the other functions. We play music with it which comes in clearer than the radio. I especially like the camera, it follows you around the room and will either zoom in so the others can see you or if you sit real close to it the camera will adjust itself to pull away from you. No more moving whatever device you use back and forth so people can see you. We had three people on one call and we could see them with no problems. It does show your surroundings so make sure no one sneaks up behind you in their skivvies. The camera will pick up other people behind you. I really did not see anything about it that I did not like. We will get good use out of this. I am glad we got this. It is an easy way to see the family and keep up with what is going on. When you visit the family there is no more comments like "look how much you have grown" or "changed" etc. I would recommend this for anyone who wants to see the kids across the country or just for everyday use. I hadn't seen my brother in over a year and now we talk with this and it like we are in the room with each other. (jw)

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: (This review is for "Portal TV" since there are reviews for multiple types of Portals mixed together here) The main reason I got Portal TV was that it connects to grandma's huge flat screen TV. We're talking heads which are 3-4 feet tall on her screen when we video chat with her. And it's in her living room where she normally sits. This permits her to see her family. Priceless. But it's really hard to set this device up for her so she can easily use it. Grandma has terrible vision and is really really bad with gadgets, especially remote controls. Asking grandma switch video inputs on her TV remote as opposed to her normally used satellite TV remote is beyond ridiculous. The Portal TV remote is so small I don't think she can even see it. Besides, the buttons on it a camouflaged by being the same color as the case. Even I couldn't see the buttons. Also, another small remote is guaranteed to be lost within a day or two. So using the Portal TV remote is not an option. Her TV wasn't new enough to auto-switch to the Portal TV HDMI feed when answering a call (ie. when Portal answers a Facebook video call). And even if it was, the TV wouldn't auto-switch back which would effectively disable her TV watching. That's her main entertainment in life right now. Cutting it off is beyond unacceptable. So instead I bought an HDMI auto-switch (HDMI Switch SGEYR 5x1 HDMI Switcher 5 in 1). But the Portal TV device doesn't turn off it's HDMI output after it hangs up on a Facebook video call, so the HDMI switcher won't auto-switch back to her TV channels. I ended up setting up a powerstrip on the table near where she sits. The Portal TV device gets it's power from the powerstrip. Before we want to do a Facebook Portal video call with her, we call her on the phone and tell her to turn on the powerstrip (it's big enough that she can see it). We wait two minutes for the Portal TV device to powerup, then we call her on Facebook video (note, you have to use "Messages" in Facebook.com. The Facebook Messenger app on Windows doesn't seem to have a video call option. Yeah, that's not confusing). She answers by saying "Hey Portal, answer" and then once connected, "Hey Portal, camera on". So I got it to work, but is was a huge hassle to setup. The Portal TV device really needs an HDMI switch that can switch to Portal TV video to answer a Facebook video call, then auto-switch back to the TV when done. Call Quality: My mom has old DSL internet service that is pretty slow. Her Portal TV device is connected via good strength WiFi (there is no ethernet port). Portal TV does a very good job of handling the low bandwidth connection. She sometimes looks a little grainy/pixelated, but the video and audio never drop out. She says that her image of us looks very good. The microphones on the Portal TV device seem to do a good job of locking in on her voice. The Portal auto-zoom on person talking seems to work fairly well, but it occasionally decides to zoom in on Grandma's walker, rather than grandma. But it's smart enough to keep grandma in the frame, so it's mostly humorous rather than a real problem. In summary, really cool device that does a good job handling low bandwidth connections and looks fantastic on the big screen.
review_header: Portal TV let's us talk to grandma! But lack of HDMI auto-switching is a major drawback

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: First off, this thing is HUGE! When I originally received it, I was surprised at how tall it is. Attached to this review is a photo showing the box sitting next to my iMac. When you take it out of the box, you can tell this is NOT a cheap plastic device. Some tech you get, you feel it will break in two weeks. This device is not like that. It has a very solid feel to it. Visually it looks like a white (or black) pillar with an iPad glued to the front. One thing that's kept video chat from being a reality in my opinion is the fact that you either have to have your face buried in your phone (FaceTime) or in front of a computer (Skype). Those work well enough, but still generally lean towards people who are more "tech-y". The commercials on TV for this device speak to a decidedly "non-techy" market with the "The Ugly Sweater Party" type commercials. Breaking into that kind of market requires a device like this, not video chat on a phone or computer. Overall the Portal device is a cool idea. I love video chat, as I moved about 1,400 miles away from my blood family awhile ago for work. So video chat is a big deal to us. The ability of this to keep track of the person talking is nice. The real world experience of it is not as slick as the TV commercials - too much moving and it pixelates a little. Not a lot, but it's not as crystal clear as the advertisements show. Still, it's one of the major selling points of the device, and it works well if not perfectly. I remember hoping that my Xbox with Kinect would pull this off, but it never really did - not like this. This works a lot better than that experience if you remember that. You can also do goofy stuff like put a cat on your head when you chat. I suppose for the "grandma and grandkids" chat selling point of this it might be a laugh, but will anyone REALLY use this feature beyond once or twice? Probably not. It is sold as having Alexa functionality, which it does to an extent. But it is not full featured. Some of the things like multi room audio and groups aren't there. You can't "drop in", and announcements aren't there. Some of the basic Alexa functionality is. Whether this affects your opinion of the device would depend on what you have done with other Echo devices, or what your expectations were here. For me, it's not a dealbreaker, as I have actual Echo devices in the same room, so I don't need that stuff. I would however like the ability to look at my Ring cameras (Amazon Echo Show devices can do that). That is not available and it would be nice if the portal was tied into that and you could use it to see what's going on at your front door with the doorbell out there. Hopefully this gets added before too long. It does have the ability to show photos from your (and your friends) Facebook posts as "screen savers" as such. That's pretty cool, but if your friends are the kinds who post obscene pictures or blue humor stuff, you might get a shock on your screen. :) There is a Facebook watch app, which is nice if you use Facebook's watch feature. I do for the live MLB streaming games - or I did in the 2018 season. As I write this in early 2019, I do not know if that's happening again, but I can easily see myself watching Facebook's MLB game streams on this. One thing I wish it would do is let me use its screen as a "second monitor" for my main desktop computer, and then interrupt me if there's an inbound call. Problem with that is there's no cable input, you'd have to bluetooth over or something along those lines. It's not nearly as cool having a Portal device in my house if the person on the other side has their face buried into their phone - which turns this into a SERIOUSLY oversized and overpriced FaceTime device. You might be better off with an Amazon Echo Show in that case. But it does what it exists for (video chat) it does extremely well. I just don't see it being your SOLE device of this kind (mostly due to the "Hey Portal" stuff being weak compared to existing AI (Alexa, Hey Google, Hey Siri).. This works well as a secondary device if you already have some other kind of home device of this nature. The likely target for Portal is those who already use Facebook messenger to communicate with their friends regularly. Are there enough people like that to sustain this as a product? I don't think so. I do wonder about the "Facebook effect" - given their issues with privacy and selling info (Cambridge Analytica), one wonders if that will impact widespread adoption of the device. I'm not one to go all George Orwell here, I do like tech. But Facebook does have a reputation for this kind of thing and "selling you" (whether they are or not is not my point - I'm talking reputation here). If this device were from someone else, I wonder if it would change anything in terms of perception. There is a way to cover the camera - it comes with a small cover for that. Still, in this age of social media (and Facebok's own 30 million user account info breach/leak), perception seems more important than reality, so I wonder how much of an impact all this will be. Will people want a video screen with a camera that looks into their home? Bottom line is this is an impressive piece of tech and works REALLY well for video chat, but needs a lot more work if it wants to grow beyond being a niche product.
review_header: REALLY great if you like Facebook Messenger chat. Beyond that it needs work.

review_text: We purchased the portal TV camera as we wanted to be able to use Zoom for our holiday family meets. We researched the portal TV as some other web cams are incompatible with our tv. On Amazon's product page, as well as the product's home page, it specifically states that it IS able to run Zoom. There are instructions specifically for how to set it up even if the app is missing. After reading and searching we opened live chat with portal. We spoke with Michael and his response was that the engineers are working on making the portal TV work with Zoom... We researched and read all available information. Once we received the camera, we set it all up and we cannot find the Zoom app anywhere! Then we searched for a 'work around'. Yep, it says just use the browser to access Zoom. We searched and searched... no browser to be seen. The portal TV is supposed to have an app for Zoom and it does not. The portal TV is also supposed to have a browser app to access the internet and it does not. We are VERY disappointed in the product information provided. They lied and falsely promoted the Portal TV as able to access Zoom. We are returning this item. Bad job Amazon.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: First off, it deserves more stars if ALL you need is to call (whatsApp) another person. Kids or parents. If you are looking for a device for your home office - stay away. Pros: - looks great. Good quality screen (rotates) and a camera - connects to Bluetooth devices (e.g. keyboard, mouse, etc.) - easy to use Cons: - no 3rd party voice or video calls supported. No jabber, no Alexa calls, no skype, no sip, no google. Nothing. - device recognized by a phone as a bluetooth speaker. You can't use it as a speakerphone with you cell. - you can't call a regular phone number (even with a fee). - it doesn't support Webex meetings. Helpdesk says that they're working on it, but no ETA. Webex (via website) does not recognize microphone / speaker, or camera. No MS Teams support, no google meet. - do you want to use it as a photo frame? Only with your facebook photos. - very few applications. 10? Useful? 2-3 max. - no email client, no calendar. Yes, you can open outlook 365 or gmail in a web browser but this is not the case. - Alexa on this device is handicapped. Most of commonly used functions not supported. - Although it is an android device, you cannot install apps from the play store. Actually you can - but you can't access them after the installation. This is the first time I decided to return an electronic device. I am done with it 3 hours after unboxing. Ugh.
review_header: Portal Plus - Great Idea, Horrible Execution

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: I have a ton of Alexa devices, so I'm largely using this as a video phone. In this regard, it's amazing. The screen is gorgeous, the microphones work great, and the camera tracks your movement. It's like a simplified enterprise teleconferencing setup for the home! Setup was refreshingly simple. It lacks a ton of features, and for now it's pretty much dependent on Facebook Messenger for calls, but Facebook being what it is, that's not exactly proprietary. The camera tracking your motion really makes this a device you can put on a table or counter and engage in conversation as you naturally walk around. That's the real benefit vs using a phone, laptop, or tablet--your hands are free. It's so much more natural, and it is a real blessing for families that are separated, especially those around the world. My sister in-law was able to connect with family in Brazil, and it felt so much more natural than traditional WhatsAp or Facebook calls on a phone. As a "smart device", it's a bit raw. The speakers are solid, as is the screen, but the Alexa implementation is incomplete vs Amazon devices. I'd suggest this for someone who doesn't have Alexa, or at least doesn't have it in the area near this device. If you're cross shopping this with an Echo Show, get the Echo Show. It's a bit more thought out. If you're looking for a great video phone setup, there's nothing better.

The beautiful screen can easily switch from portrait to landscape and back. It also replaced our digital picture frame. Our favorite time is breakfast at the dining nook by the kitchen and saying ‚ÄúHey Portal, call <name>‚Äú, add <call> other family members, and enjoy a morning group video call. Then after our morning call, say ‚ÄúAlexa, play <iHeart radio>‚Äù. This is the best gadget in our house.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: The video calling works well- better call quality than Hangouts, almost as good as Apple. You can set people as favorites so you don‚Äôt have to scroll to your friends list when you want to call. Unfortunately, usage is really hampered by the need to switch input away from what you are watching to make or receive a call, a clunky process on most TV‚Äôs. Alternatively, you could use the device as your primary player but that is not a good option for all but a few people. Really sub par as a media player- has Facebook watch (bad, not a lot of variety) Amazon Prime (good) and Spotify (ok, I guess). There are other video apps but they are not even worth mentioning. To be worth using as a media player it needs to catch up others- Hulu, Netflix, and Disney + at a minimum. Either that, or video pass-through would do it.
review_header: Good video calling, terrible media player (more important than you‚Äôd think)

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: I've been using Skype to call my parents who live 800 miles away for years, and I kept wishing there was a simple "webcam with built-in Skype" that I could just connect to my TV, rather than trying to crowd my family around my computer to talk. So when the Portal TV came out I got one for myself and one for my parents as soon as I could. It was fairly easy to setup both for me and for my parents (with a little help from me over the phone). Once or twice per call the AI camera focus will randomly wander off and highlight an empty corner of the room, but otherwise the video and audio quality are good. The voice navigation is great; I can turn it on, make a video call, hang up at the end of the call, and turn it off all with voice commands without touching the remote. It also plays Netflix and Amazon Video and some other things, but those don't support voice commands, so we just stick with using our PS4 for those like we did before we got the Portal TV. Facebook recently added Zoom support to every Portal EXCEPT the Portal TV, which is frustrating; maybe Zoom is working on their own set-top camera and didn't want Portal TV to compete. It would also be nice to be able to use Skype or Hangouts on the Portal TV, but obviously Facebook wants to keep everything within their own ecosystem and support their competition as little as possible. Another minor annoyance is that the remote has an accelerometer that's not used for anything, but if you nudge the remote (or nudge a table that the remote is sitting on) then it'll wake up the Portal TV. Although my parents and I call each other directly from one Portal TV to another, it can call anything that can run Facebook Messenger video, so you can also use it to video chat with someone via their phone, or computer with webcam, or non-TV Facebook Portal device. It also has a black plastic shutter that you can slide over the camera to make extra sure that Facebook isn't randomly spying on your living room while you're not using it, if that's a concern you have. So far there's still zero competition in the "webcam with built-in video chat that you just connect to your TV" market, so if you want to be able to video call people from your TV and don't mind being tied to only being able to make video calls via Facebook Messenger, then this is the device for you.
review_header: good at what it does, but doesn't do a lot

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: Short Summary: Get this if you want an easy and excellent video calling experience with FB Messenger contacts Detailed Review: Portal from Facebook. Smart Video Calling with Alexa Built-in ‚Äì 10‚Äù Screen makes video calling an easy and satisfying experience for individuals who enjoy talking with their Facebook friends. The Portal design has made privacy a priority. The calls are encrypted and voice interactions can be reviewed and deleted or the storage can be turned off completely. There is also a button that visibly blocks the camera lens. If one desires even more privacy, both camera and microphone can be disabled by sliding a switch. A red light appears to indicate that they are turned off. I have been using various video calling equipment and apps for almost 15 years and the Portal is the best yet and definitely the easiest to use. After plugging in the Portal, one only has to log in to their FB account and their messenger contact list immediately appears. A green circle indicates which of the contacts is currently active. The person called by the Portal only needs to have a messenger app on any device in order to receive the call. The picture that one sees on the Portal will depend on the quality of that person‚Äôs device camera. Video calling with someone who also has a Portal or has Messenger installed on a device with a high end camera, like the Pixel 4 or iphone 11 is definitely optimal. The Portal makes it easy to do group calls too. There are fun effects that one can use during the call or in the photo booth which can capture both still photos and videos that can easily be sent to friends. The clarity and color of the transmission are spot on but the biggest advance is the ability of the camera to follow someone as they move about a room. One can also select an individual to spotlight which is nice, especially when there are several people in the room. The capacity of the camera to pan and zoom as needed is so impressive and makes video calls feel more like an actual visit. The Portal even automatically adjusts the volume as one moves farther or closer to the device. The sound quality is excellent and the calls are crystal clear without someone having to ask for things to be repeated. Alexa is built into the Portal and is designed so that one doesn‚Äôt have to go through the ‚Äòhey Portal‚Äô wake up but instead can just say ‚ÄòAlexa‚Äô. This is a handy way to control smart home devices or use various Alexa skills. I was happy to see a quick response when I asked Alexa to stream my Wyze video cameras. It‚Äôs easy to link the Portal to an Amazon account. There are also other built in apps and website icons including YouTube, Google search, Facebook and numerous news outlets and popular apps and sites. A WhatsApp can also be linked in settings. The ten inch Portal is designed to look like a solid and attractive picture frame that can be used in either landscape or portrait mode. The 4.75‚Äù stand gives it a firm footing in either orientation. It doesn‚Äôt appear that the Portal is designed to compete with either the Amazon Echo or the Google Hub. Each device has its own unique features and abilities. The Portal by Facebook will be best appreciated by those who use FB Messenger and/or WhatsApp as their primary social media source. For users of those apps, the Portal is an excellent choice for high quality video calls. Giving a Portal as a gift to a family member who is not technically proficient but would like to have the ability to easily have a virtual visit with friends and family is a wonderful choice. Portal from Facebook is easy to use, has privacy settings to minimize concerns and makes video calling a five star experience. Everything else about it is just a bonus.
review_header: Excellent design for FB Messenger users

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: Video Conferencing used to be something we‚Äôd only see in Sci-Fi stories. From Star Trek‚Äôs view screen, to the ‚ÄúBell System‚Äù video phone booth in 2001: A Space Odyssey, those scenes and moments were something dreams were made of. When video chat started to make its way to our PC‚Äôs in the 90s, I was really excited. While it wasn‚Äôt seamless and you really had to work at finding someone, anyone to chat with, it truly was exciting times. Flash forward to now where we take video conferencing for granted and there are now so many options. From Skype, to Apple‚Äôs Facetime to Google‚Äôs really underrated Duo, we have more options than ever. Beyond the little known video conferencing options with the Microsoft Kinect, nothing has come close to innovating like the Facebook Portal Plus. The first thing you will notice about the Portal Plus is the awesome packaging. Everything is easy to open and clearly marked on how to open. You even get a nice ‚ÄúHi‚Äù in the box. Right away, everything screams quality and something special. You also get a camera cover if you want more peace of mind when not using the camera. That said, you will be able to mute mic and turn of camera by a button. Setting up the Portal Plus is also so very easy. You are directed to a website to enter a code and you must use Facebook Messenger. Once that is setup, the rest is easy and it takes over and completes a few more setup steps and it is ready to go. The primary screen is your video calling page, where it suggests friends to call. At first, mine was suggesting people I never once sent Facebook Messages to but it has finally set to mostly family suggestions, which is perfect. The second screen features a handful of apps you can use but more on that later. Video calling. It is what the Portal is all about, right? I will go ahead and say this now. This is the best video conferencing device that I have ever used. Period. No doubts about it. I thought Skype with the XBOX One and the Kinect was awesome. But this truly blows me away. The video and sound are just so crisp and clear. Everyone we tested with were equally impressed and they were only using their phones. On the Plus, you can also rotate between portrait and landscape mode and it is a joy to use. Landscape is my favorite mode. Smart Camera is truly something to behold. As mentioned, I used the Kinect with Skype and it has some tracking but not like the Portal has. Smart Camera truly can follow you across an entire room. I tested this in my living room and you can go end to end and it can still track you. It also focuses on the speaker and can help drown out background noise so that the receiver can hear the primary speaker. Also, it can frame a shot so if there are multiple people in the frame, it works hard on making sure it looks great and proper focus to both people in the foreground and background. Smart Camera is the true selling point of the Facebook Portal. There are some apps and features worth mentioning. The story time mode is so cute and perfect for grandkids sending their stories to their grandparents. Just love this feature. It also has a few music apps such as Pandora, Spotify and I Heart Radio. You can also let it show a slideshow of your photos from Facebook. While not as good as what you can get on a Google Home Hub device, this works fine. I‚Äôd like to see some updates to the slide show, like being able to select ALL photos and a better randomizing algorithm. At the time of this review, there was a new update released but I‚Äôve not received it as of yet. It is to include a browser among other good enhancements. Amazon Alexa integration works well though it isn‚Äôt as full featured as what you will get with a full Echo device. I was able to ask question, reorder items from Amazon and general use and it worked great. There are so many options these days for video conferencing platforms and devices. If you and your family are Facebook Messenger users, I have to wholeheartedly recommend the Facebook Portal. Not only are you staying on a common messaging platform, but you are getting the absolute best camera you can get.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: This is actually a very interesting device with very high-quality audio and video and pretty amazing video "follow me" capability. But it also has one very glaring deficiency: if you have this set up to turn on and off your TV between calls (which works very well), you have NO idea WHO is calling you when a call comes in, as there is no speaker or even small LCD on the unit itself. There is one easy and obvious solution to this, and why Facebook hasn't implemented is beyond me: I suspect many users may have an Alexa audio-only unit nearby, and why given the Portal TV already has Alexa integration there isn't a (user settable) option to announce WHO is calling on Alexa is inexplicable. But at the moment the ony way (unless you have a cell phone or PC at hand) to find out WHO is calling is to answer it on the TV. Alexa alaready has this integration for landline phones if you buy the Amazon Alexa phone interface, so why FB chose not to also allow this for Portal is beyond me as the hard work (Alexa integration) is already done.
review_header: Pretty Amazing Device with one Glaring Misfeature: no effective "caller id"

review_text: The device functionality is actually pretty cool, when it works. But be prepared - it‚Äôs terrible in a mid-range WiFi area. You basically need it to sit right next to your router, which limits where you can actually use it. We placed ours in our kitchen, only one room away from our office where the router is, and all day long kept hearing pulsing sounds from the Portal as it disconnected and reconnected to the network. At first, Portal‚Äôs customer service was responsive and helpful, until I sent them a video of the problem and they handed me to one of the ‚Äútechnical experts‚Äù who basically repeated the same troubleshooting process as their frontline staff. Subpar product with subpar customer service. Wouldn‚Äôt buy again.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: This was purchased so we could video chat our family who lives across the country. This device only works portal to portal OR portal to phone or tablet. I have a laptop (MacBook and a PC) and the facebook messenger does NOT receive calls from the portal device. We even try calling the portal from facebook messenger and our family's portal does not receive theca's. The only way is when we use our cell phones. The entire point of this purchase was so our family could have a hands free way of calling us. We don't need the portal because we have many other means of video chatting. Now we cannot return this product since it is past the return window and cannot use it for the purpose it was purchased for. I'm glad my family has a big screen to use but now we have to look at them on a tiny phone screen. DO NOT BUY THIS UNLESS WHOEVER YOU'RE CALLING HAS A PORTAL DEVICE. What a ridiculous design. Oh and BTW I called the portal support and they told me they are well aware of the problem and are "trying to fix it". Glad I paid full price for a worthless spinning tablet with very limited capabilities.
review_header: WASTE OF MONEY. DO NOT BUY!

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: So first off this for portal TV, I have family and friends all over the world and i frequently miss life events fr birthdays, to holidays etc. I picked up portal tv in hopes of remedying this a bit and i have no regrets. It has exceeded my expectations and brought more functionality into my living room than before. Small example, alexa cant turn on my tv with a voice command, portal can. The quality is great, video and sound and its a great experience being able to sit on the couch and have a conversation as if me and the person i called were in the same room. Its more personal and you are not holding a phone in your face for the duration of the call. Lets talk privacy real quick, yes it has a camera cover and a mic mute button. If you are still paranoid about facebook tracking your living room activities you better throw your smartphone in the trash cause i have news for you, in the age of technology you are being passively monitored 24/7. Not saying giving them more access is good but dont kid yourself if you think you are off the grid by any means. I gain far more from this than they do, so the risk vs reward is mitigated. My biggest complaints/ recommendations so far. 1. It would be great to have the camera lens open remotely at the push of a button. A little motor that moves the lense physically so i sont have to get up to open/ close it for each call. 2. It be great if it had hand gesture tracking to zoom in or out. Trying to show off an object can be a bit annoying trying to fit it in the frame when it focuses on your face. 3. It doesnt track all family members, especially the ones that bark. It would be nice if my dog was tracked to so it would put him in the frame when hes on the couch with me. 4. This ties into point 3. It would be great if we could pick certain callers that will automatically answer the call. This way you could set it up to check in on your pet to. Say im out and about, i call the camera itself, it turns on the tv and automatically answers for my predetermined number. Lastly, and this is my biggest issue with portal TV, its not as international yet as it should be. I think this is a matter of time but its still a huge issue. Many countries do not have this available yet so when i call there they are still bound to holding a phone in their face. I know more EU countries are being added soon but there are still many that arent. I hope this gets addressed soon. Anyways, overall this product is perfect if you live thousands of miles from loved ones. if you live locally however, just be a decent person and meet in person.
review_header: Portal TV: perfect for international living

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: I am a Millennial (aka otherwise tech savvy) who purchased two of these for both my grandparents. I tried it out first, and it worked very well when I called my friends and family who ALREADY had a facebook. So before Christmas, I unboxed the two for my grandparents and started the process of making a facebook for them. I was a little disappointed that there wasn't a way to add facebook contacts using whatsapp (because a whatsapp account was much easier to set up), but I wasn't concerned because I had already made new emails for both of my grandparents for their google home accounts. BUT WHAT DO YOU KNOW! In all of facebook's infinite wisdom, both emails were rejected and their accounts disabled before I could even get to the part of adding a picture for them. Don't know why, all it said was that somehow my 100 year old violated the community guidelines. I immediately clicked for facebook to do a review, there must be a mistake. Facebook said they would gladly do a review if I provided a phone number they could text. HOW DOES A 100 YEAR OLD RESPOND TO A TEXT?!?! and of course I can't use my phone because it's already attached to my account. So what do I do here? There is no number to call, no help desk to complain. Facebook sells this product on being a great easy way to communicate with the elderly, but does nothing to make it easy to get set up. I literally have no idea what to do other than keep trying different emails until maybe the great facebook will be gracious enough to let me video chat with my Grandparents.

So bottom line, I with I would have bought the smaller set and use the device to just phone calls.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: CONS - No Zoom Support. I bought this device so I could take video calls from my living room TV. Facebook promoted their support for Zoom, which is what I use for most video calls. Then when the Portal TV arrived, I was dismayed to find that Zoom support is for all Portal devices EXCEPT the Portal TV. Damn. - Cannot use if you're smart TV is hooked up and using HDMI-CEC and ARC. I have an Apple TV and Amazon Fire TV which are hooked into my LG TV via HDMI. I can use one remote for all of them, they turn on/off automatically, and audio for all of them goes into the TV and back out via one HDMI cable to my Yamaha Receiver. It works perfectly, until Portal TV is plugged in. I tested multiple HDMI ports and switching them up, and it's definitely the Portal TV. When it's plugged in my TV cannon send audio to the Yamaha receiver via ARC and the CEC communication is blocked, so auto-input switching and auto on/off no longer works. I read many other users having this same problem, and Facebook told me they're aware of the problem and working on it. PROS - Good video quality. I've had a few video calls with family and friends via WhatsApp on the Portal TV. They all told me the video quality they're receiving of me was very good. There is an option to switch landscape/portrait mode, and this is helpful for people calling me via their phone...as the portrait mode crops the video and gives them a closer view of me and yet is still a good resolution. - Auto-zooming / following. Generally this works pretty well, and makes it more convenient for me to be natural in my environment...getting up and walking around and yet the other party still sees me in the center of the frame. - Privacy shield/button. Good for them on including this. Easy to cover the camera and also hit the side button to disable audio/video. UNDECIDED - Audio quality. So far I have not been able to successfully use audio through the TV. There is about a 2 second delay which makes the calls unworkable. I was able to connect the Portal TV to my Bluetooth headset and this was satisfactory. I'm not sure why the 2 second delay, and this could be a problem if you need to use the Portal TV through speakers vs. using a Bluetooth headset.
review_header: Zoom does not work. Breaks ARC and HDMI-CEC functionality.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: update:1/22/2021: It is now 1.5 years and the portal+ is still going strong. My original comments still apply. The video call is it's main purpose and best use case. It's still loud and the camera is awesome as it pans to where there is motion or voice. It does work from 25-30 feet away. We have it on continuously so the portal updates itself occasionally. We have had to do a couple reboots in this 1.5 years but in general it works. They did add one capability which I like: I can now create a 'superframe' folder in my facebook account and direct portal to display only those photos in round robin fashion. So now I have control of what gets seen and when. I put a small number of photos into that folder and change the photos periodically. I am still hopeful the other 2 capabilities will show up in the near future (remote administration, auto answer). I got portal plus about 9 months ago. It is great as a video chat device. The main benefit I saw is that display is large and the speakers are loud and voice control is available. This is used for the grandparents who are computer illiterate and somewhat hard of hearing. The speakers are loud so they can really hear me . It's volume is adjustable too for those not so deaf. This loudness was definitely required. When they video chat with me I can hear them fine too so the microphone is sensitive. This means whether they stand up close of talk from the kitchen (30 ft away). The display is larger that a tablet and we put it in landscape mode (can be portrait too) . Our goal is it is a device that just sits there and needs no attention like a landline telephone. It will take multiple calls at once ie video conference so the most we've had is 3 people call at once. All 3 were displayed simultaneously. The other thing that helps illiteracy is they can just answer by saying " hey portal answer". We did not want them to touch the device or initiate call. 'superframe' is what they call the display of pictures when not in a call. So we load it with tons of pictures and somehow it cycles and displays pictures. Not just what I load up but what I also put in their facebook account. I'm unclear as to when and what pictures get displayed. Easy to answer if you have just a few photos but if you have hundreds+ then I don't know which ones get chosen over time. So every week or so I add photos to their facebook account and hope newer ones show up. Lots of other capabilities but it accomplished our main objectives. Some features that I hope will come in future: 1) remote administration - so I can program /adjust as needed 2) auto answer - so I can check up on them and they don't have to do anything to answer 3) superframe - better control of what and when pictures show up. Click HELPFUL if you find this of benefit .

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: Right out of the box, this device impresses with its build quality. It's a stunning piece of tech and impeccably made. The screen is huge and rotates effortlessly. The whole thing is rock solid and feels like something Apple would make. It's worth noting that it's quite large, which is great on one level but it takes up quite a bit of space for a device with pretty limited features (at least for now). The web-cam is a cool approach. It uses a 180 deg fisheye lens and then the software tracks your movement to follow you. That way you're free to move around while you chat and the software keeps you in frame all the time. This feature works pretty well with one person but it seemed to get confused on who to follow when my wife and I were in the frame together. I couldn't find a way to override this feature but, again, it's just software so there's no reason to think they won't refine it over time. As a digital picture frame, it also performs quite well. You can point it at any Facebook albums and it'll rotate through the photos. The one big weakness of this device in a household is that you have to lock it into one Facebook profile. So the ability to have multiple users in the house is not currently practical. That sucks on a few levels - at least in our house. It seems like something they could address though.

review_text: This is an interesting concept. The selling point is the camera. It's best for a group of people, all wanting to be seen, video chatting. You can go online there are apps, websites and a browser. This device only works when plugged in it doesn't charge up. The sound is excellent. There is no audio outlet for headphones. It's easy to make a video call through messenger. It has a stand so it'll stand up wide ways or long ways. Now for the cons: Within a handful of quick uses every site stopped working. The only thing left working is Amazon. If I'm streaming in Amazon I only get so far before it stops with an error message. As far as the video chat goes on our side we look good to who is talking to us, but I didn't think the picture looked any better than when I use my phone or tablet. Personally I find it more convenient to use my phone or tablet so I can move around. I think this is an unnecessary product and recommends spending your money on a more practical device.

So the larger screen is just for being able to see people better, not to see them from farther away.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: We moved 1,000 miles away from both my family and my husband‚Äôs family, a few years ago. Our children were still small and we wanted to try our best to form a continued connection between them and our families, despite the distance. We tried skype and facetime on our phones, computers, and tablets, but found that the children either interrupted the communication by covering the entire camera or making faces at it, to watch themselves on the small screen, or ran away with the phone entirely wanting to communicate but ending up showing our parents a very uninteresting view of the ceiling. We were sad and frustrated and so were our parents, but we figured it was developmental and that our children would grow out of it. Then a friend told me about Portal tv and how it had completely changed video calling with her child and parents. We were hopeful, but skeptical when we ordered it, as it just may have been a difference between her child and ours lol. However, she was correct! Portal not only puts the picture on the television, but the camera can mount high meaning that the children cannot cover the entire screen! It is super simple to install and setup and makes video calling effortless. It pans in and out to follow movement and allows the person on the other end of the call to see and hear everyone equally! It has vastly improved our calls and makes us feel like our parents are right in the room! I‚Äôd recommend this to everyone!
review_header: Game changer for video calls with kids

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: I bought 1 portal plus and 1 portal for the sole purpose of using the video calling function for my elderly Father. Unlike Amazon Echo Show, it has simple to use touchscreen buttons which my Father can learn to use. However, the portal devices require a Facebook account in order to use the video calling function. So I signed up a Facebook account for my Father for this purpose, putting in his real name and photo. After setting everything up, including adding friends and family to his list of contacts to call, Facebook locked his account, citing suspicious activity. Facebook requested another photo to unlock his account but after submitting this photo his account remains locked. So sitting in his living room is this expensive brick. If any other company sells you a device which requires a membership to use and yet does not allow you to get that membership, it would be considered a scam.
review_header: Facebook don‚Äôt let you use the portal devices after purchase

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: I'd seen the Facebook Portal commercials and ads online but hadn't really given much thought to getting one. My phone has video calling/chatting/Face timing and so does my tablet. My computer has a webcam so I can/have used Skype and other video apps/sites before. But when I got this Portal and was setting it up I realized that I could call anyone through Facebook if they have one too or not. So anyone that has a Facebook with a connected phone number you can call them! It's fun and easy to use if you use the video chat feature or just treat it like a phone. The video quality is really great and the camera follows you/them as you move which is nice in case you're doing something like cleaning, cooking, or getting ready for example. It's a good size screen being 10 inches and the sound quality is great too. I like using Youtube through it as well. It has a really nice touch screen that responds just as well if not better than my phone and tablet. Oh and it has Alexa as a voice assistant built right in! So I can say "Call Mike Jones or pull up Youtube" and it'll do as instruction. Basically, the Facebook Portal has multiple uses and is really high quality! I can definitely say that I'm surprised yet glad to be able to honestly recommend it! I think it would make a fantastic and fun gift idea as well with the Holidays coming up. It's great to get in-touch with the ones you love and care about family, friends, or otherwise. :)

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: Portal TV is without doubt the best device for video calling your near and dear ones. Pros: - The device and remote is sleek and modern looking. - Great video quality. - Works with Facebook and WhatsApp which are the most used chat services. - Wide field of view, dynamic pan and zoom when you move. It is amazing to video call friends and family with this device. - The discount on bundle of 2 is great deal since you can give one to your family and use the glorious way to video chat. - Physical buttons to cover the camera and mute the microphone resolves concerns with privacy. Cons: - Facebook's track record might not appeal to others. I didn't care much about it with the physical buttons to disable camera and microphone. - Uses an HDMI port on your TV so if you are using a TV with fewer HDMI ports, you wouldn't want to spare one just for video chat. - On my LG OLED TV since the screen is so thin, I cant put it on top and need to place below my TV on top of my soundbar which I hate.
review_header: Portal TV: Best Video Calling Device

Now mind you, he didn't think much of Alexa before this, and couldn't understand why I had bought 6 more dots. I had our son, who is serving a mission for our church away from home, call us on messanger. HUBBY GONE WILD! He adores it!!! We conference with kids, (we have 9), and grandkids, (18 of them spread out everywhere). We can literally be there with them and read a book, say prayers, watch a game, etc., with the Portal. He called everyone he knew on it, just to tell them how cool it was and to show them the zoom and pan features it has. He struts around the kitchen while we make dinner, do dishes, eat breakfast and so on. Then I showed him what Alexa can do, and started a playlist for him on Spotify. He has 1010 songs! In 2 weeks! He has demanded a dot be put in his office and the garage, even by the pool. Don't think about it, just buy it! The Plus is worth the extra money. We are saving up to get each of our kids and parents a Plus for Christmas this year. I trust Amazon, so buying refurbished doesn't scare me one bit.

review_text: Zoom is supported on the Portal devices, but not Portal TV. Facebook Live is supported on the Portal devices, but not Portal TV. Even some of the media coverage advertising the recent (3Q20) availability of Zoom incorrectly reports it as available for "Portal TV," but they mean the tablet-type devices, not this. A Wired review from August, 2020 says "The various new apps will be added throughout September on the Portal, Portal+, and Portal Mini, but won‚Äôt come to Portal TV until later in 2020." But they didn't. Facebook seems to be committed to the Portal tablet-type devices, but this thing seems to be the abandoned stepchild in terms of feature set.

review_header: Best for family meetings during covid

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: Being 3 states away with two small girls and lots of family a portal is great for chats. I might argue that the base model portal would be better with kids as it would be easier to move around to different rooms. That said when walking around the room that it is in it does an amazing job following you and widening to pick up other people who come in. The movement is butter smooth almost like there is a professional cameraman behind the scenes. Every once in a while you may have to move around a little for it to pick up on you being there and include you in the frame but that is more the exception than the rule. The video, sound and voice pickup quality are all top notch too. Something we noticed is that while you can share the augmented reality masks and faces the storytime function is limited by only allowing a portal device to be the one reading the story. When you're the one with kids and the portal it doesn't do any good. It's nice that you can make calls entirely by voice though the confirmation question every time is a little annoying. It could be useful to avoid accidental dials but from what I've seen the microphone and software works so well it isn't needed. You can also have more than one Facebook profile which is a must have for multiple sets of friends in a household and if for nothing else than allowing my wife to call me or me to call her depending on who's away. First and foremost it is a video chat device and while it is almost flawless there the secondary uses and their limitation are at sometimes annoying and infuriating at others. Want to listen to pandora? Sure you can start it with your voice but to choose a station you have to walk over and touch it anyway. Surely you can view a recipe on this thing right? Nope, not even a web browser to speak of. Display photos of your family? You better have them all in an album on Facebook because that is the only place you can use for the photo frame. Maybe we're not most people but that isn't how we use Facebook. It's a lot of one-off pictures that no one wants to see every day in a photo frame. Then there's Alexa. We use her heavily in our house for communicating across the house and performing various smart home tasks. Keeping the portal in the kitchen seems like a good way to have an all in one device. The limitations here are mind blowing. First, the microphone on this is so sensitive that it picks up "Alexa" from other rooms and unlike an actual Echo doesn't realize you're closer to another one. It takes over which ruins room grouping and sometimes it just can't do things like "drop in". Then you've got a giant screen so you'd think it would work like an Echo show and allow you to for instance view a security camera. Nope, can't do that either. If I ask it to play music from my Plex server it says ok and then never plays any audio. The 3rd party integration leave a ton to be desired and in my opinion aren't ready. There just isn't enough there and it feels incomplete. I've been conflicted when giving this a rating. On one hard it's main function is to make great video calls and it does that. On the other, it advertises a bunch of functionality that feels half baked. For a device this size it should be an all-in-one and I would be willing to bet a lot of people will buy one assuming it can do that. The problem is that it can't and it's disappointing when trying to do these other things. It needs more photo sources, more apps, and more functionality for the ones it has. It is on software version 1.0.0 so hopefully there will be a lot of additions when there is finally an update.
review_header: VIdeo calls are great but the other parts are just annoying in their limitations

review_text: Note: The FB Portal Plus is not meant to be a tablet competitor. There is not a lot of storage, and it is not meant for heavy app usage outside of what is provided. That being said: for that it is the FB Portal Plus is a blast. The video quality in calls is great, and everyone we have chatted with so far days our video feed is stellar. The video tracking feature is fun as well, but ultimately not that important to the video chatting experience. We use the Alexa feature heavily in our house, and also use the Facebook photos feature to rotate through pictures as a rotating background wallpaper. Also: The hands free feature to start and end calls is nice. It's very apparent that Portal has a very limited command vocabulary compared to, say, Alexa which understands tons of commands. I assume in future iterations these commands will be broadened and made more intuitive. I think the Portal Plus is fun, if not a little on the expensive side for what it is.
