product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: Our mom, 88 YOA, lives with me and my sister, miles away. I thought this would be a great way for mom and my sister to stay in touch. However, neither me nor my sister are able to make it work. We both have Smart TV‚Äôs but can‚Äôt connect to the network. The Geek Squad is also bewildered as to why it will not work. We have done what both the paperwork and what is on line explains to do with no results. Where do we going from here?

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: Set Up: The set up of Portal was easy. I pretty much screwed in the bar that holds it up as well as the power source. You then turn the Portal on and follow the steps. I utilized my Facebook app to set it up. It does take a couple minutes to download Portal software to the device, which I thought was weird. I would have assumed the device would already come with the software it needs to work. Use: Using Portal to make video calls is easy. Once you're logged in, you can make video calls to other people who have Facebook Messenger installed on their phones. We used it to call my mother in law and my sister in law. I found this was an easy way to do video calling and my toddler seems to enjoy it too. The camera is one of those smart ones, so basically it stays focused on you as you move around. I liked that this can be all hands free. Using Alexa works well on this device too. You just give it voice commands and it works. Unfortunately, we have the portal set up next to an Echo dot which can get annoying. I'd recommend not putting them next to each other. Also, name your Portal something different than the room it is in. For us, when we say turn the living room off, it not only turns off our lights, but also the portal. The super frame is a cool feature, where it works as a digital photo frame. However, it really shows like the same six photos for fifteen seconds each. To make a change, it makes you log into your facebook account. I don't like constantly logging into my account on my phone to make changes when I am already logged in on the device. You can have a couple different FB accounts logged into Portal. As for privacy, there's a switch that can turn off the camera. You also determine which information saves and which does not. Probably the most annoying thing about Portal, as a person with a toddler who keeps this device at a level he can reach, is that to set a passcode on the device so he doesn't randomly call someone from college that I haven't spoken with in ten years, you need to log into your FB app first and can't just do it from Portal. I think that's a really annoying and flawed piece of functioning. This is a really neat device when it comes to video calling and I like that it is loud when playing my music via Alexa. However, a lot of what this device does can also be done via a tablet or iPad.
review_header: A Neat Device - But Other Devices Can Do The Same Thing Easier

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: This is amazing. I tried out a different video frame before for my 95 year old dad, but it was a bit to complicated for him to use. I thought I'd give the Facebook portal a try and it has worked out better than I could have imagined. I love it so much I bought a second one for myself. My dad lives in another state in an assisted living facility. With the pandemic they aren't allowing visitors. I'm not sure when I'll be able to visit him next, but the portal is like a virtual visit. He can be almost anywhere in the main room of his apartment and it will follow him around. It really feels like I'm in the room with him. It really is amazing. My dad isn't technical, but with the portal he doesn't have to be. He uses the Alexa commands to call people and answer a call. Before I sent it to him I created a facebook account for him and added all of my brothers and sisters. All he had to do is connect it to his wifi. The only thing I wish they would improve, the voice assistant doesn't respond if you don't have wifi. It would be nice if it would response enough to let you set up wifi. It also doesn't have voice commands to dim the screen. My brother was a bit hesitant to use it because he's not a fan of video chat programs like Zoom or Facetime. He's rather just talk on the phone. After trying it he's a believer. It has a completely different feel than other video chat programs. Instead of someone's face on your screen it feels like you're in the room with the person you're talking to. I bought one for myself so I could set it in a desk and "hang out" with my dad. we talk and play games.
review_header: Bought for my dad and love it!

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: An amazing product for video calling. My nice keeps asking me to tell her the stories almost every day, hope they and more stories in the future. The rest besides the video calling needs to be improved.
review_header: Video calling 5 stars.. The rest is not that impressive.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: Facebook advertises this thing constantly as being compatible with Zoom and other videoconferencing services. Only after I bought it did I see the fine print: Only the models with the built-in screen have Zoom (they say it's coming at some point, but not right now). That means the utility of this is sharply limited. You can only use it for Facebook Messenger video calls. I love it the few times I've used it -- it puts a call with the grandparents on the biggest screen in the house, and the smart camera follows my kids around as they run, jump and show off. It's the next best thing to being there in person. But until they expand the functionality, it's not going to get much usage.
review_header: Cool smart camera, but no Zoom.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: It's a hugely disappointing product at least in its initial release. Basically it's a very expensive, big video telephone for making calls to other people who also own a Facebook portal, with very little other useful features. You can also use it as an extremely large, very expensive electric picture frame, to cycle through your Facebook photos. I was initially excited by the whole thing: it's very very big, so if you want a really big tablet mounted on what amounts to a not very good Amazon Alexa-like device, there's that. In the setup process they demonstrate what I think is a pretty cool feature: the built-in camera kind of follows you around the room - kind of neat example of AI technology, I think. Here's what I find so disappointing: the most obvious use for this thing, I think, would be to "go live" on Facebook, basically video blogging, but incredibly, you can't do that. As far as I can tell you really can only use this thing to contact other people who have Facebook portal devices. There are lots of other ways to do video chatting but if you have money to burn, and two people who would like to frequently do video chats, you might enjoy these portals. Another nice feature: the packaging is really top-notch. Outstanding. That's important in a product so useless, because you'll want to return it within 30 minutes of setting it up.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: If you're using this for grandma to talk with the grandkids, it's perfect. Don't even question it, just get it. For anything beyond that, the software is far too immature. Seems like a beta product. I use two of them to talk between my two offices in two different physical locations. There is no "mute" button on the device to mute the playing audio, so when I get a phone call or a customer walks in, I have to walk to the device and physically press the side buttons until the volume is down and then when I'm done, walk back to the device and physically keep tapping "up" until the audio is where I want it. I thought a solution would be to connect an Echo Dot (since it has a physical mute button" and the Portal connects to it, and identifies it as a bluetooth headset, but won't send audio to it! A couple quick software fixes would easily make this a 5-star product. I am talking with support to see if I can get these fixed implemented and if so, I will modify my rating.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: Most of the reviews I have read about the portal and portal+ were critical of Facebook and the device. They were woefully inaccurate. Firstly, it does what it is designed to do superbly - that is make video calls. It is way more functional that most devices in that I can actually make international calls with no problems. I just held a chat with my niece in England. The video was not perfect as she was on a cell phone but it was smooth and only slightly fuzzy. With a laptop or better still anther portal, the video is excellent. The fact that you do not have to have a portal at both ends makes it way more functional than devices like the Amazon Echo Show. Add to that the artificial intelligence that is built in to track and frame the caller which is just amazing. I can move around the room and I am free to do whater I want without worrying if I am wandering out of frame. The Portal is competitively priced compared to the Echo Show and the Protal+ is well worth the extra to get the larger screen which makes video calling seem like you are almost in the same room. It also makes adjustments for the ambient light in the room. The sound quality is excellent. While it lacks some functionality, it does have Amazon's Alexa built in. For someone like myself with Echo's around the house, it means I do not have to learn a whole new set of commands for things I am already used to doing. Some writers criticized the fact that you need to use "Hey Portal...‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶." for Facebook functionality (primarily making calls) to "Alexa...‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶." for Amazon functions but it really is not that difficult to handle. In terms of what it can and cannot do, there are really few limits. It will turn on and off my Alexa devices and control the thermostat. It has a built in web browser so that, for instance, you can go to YouTube and play videos. So far, I am delighted with the device. some critics have panned Facebook for it's security record but it collects no more from the portal than it does when you use facebook on your phone or laptop. Facebook promises additional features and improvements in the near future. I'll look forward to added features but even without them, I am happy with the unit which does exactly what it was designed for and so much more.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: I use video conferencing apps pretty often for work...Zoom, Google Meet, etc. They work ok, but I don't feel like I'm really there with the other people. Since I live out-of-'town from my family, and travel is not an option during the pandemic, I wanted a way to feel close and stay in contact. I've tried video calls on iPhone, IPad pro (12.9"), computers, and the smaller Portal. They work, but all have their problems. Most issues for me relate to sound quality. Either I can't hear the other people due to my speakers not reproducing voices clearly (or I have to put on headphones but then no one else in the room can hear the conversation), they can't hear me due to my mic or my position to the mic, or the software cuts people off while it negotiates audio input and output at the same time. The smaller screens of phones and tablets are also unpleasant for a call more than a few minutes long. This thing solves those problems. I've also tried the smaller Portal and it was ok, but really not much better than a tablet. The camera tracking was nice, but the audio quality wasn't great and I felt like the screen was too small...which detracts from the experience of mimicking a real visit. The only downside to me is you're locked into the Facebook ecosystem, so as far as I know you can't use it with other services. I'm kind of surprised no competitors have produces something comparable yet. But if you can't visit friends or family and want to keep in contact with them, it's worth it for both parties to get one of these. Two of these would be about the same price as one plane ticket, that you can use it over and over, without catching Covid.
review_header: Beats video calls on phones, tablets computers, and the smaller Portal

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: This review is for the Portal Plus from Facebook. Smart, Hands-Free Video Calling with Alexa Built-in. This is basically a tablet screen hooked permanently to a stand containing a speaker, microphone and camera. The picture, video and audio quality is excellent. Set-up was easy. The price however is too high (should never retail for more than $249). My main complaint is the lack of apps. Mine came with Facebook Watch, YouTube, Newsy, Pandora, Spotify, iHeart Radio, Food Network. No Netflix, Hulu Plus, Skype, Nord VPN, Vudu, Amazon Music or Amazon Ptime Movies to mention a few. Skype is important because with Skype you cannot only video conference with other Skype members, but you can make non-video calls to any phone using your Skype credit. Makes no difference whether the person has a Facebook or Messenger account at all. Nord VPN is critical to protect your records and calls from Facebook and future data breaches at Facebook. The product description says "Facebook doesn't listen to, view or keep the contents of your Portal video calls. Calls on Portal are encrypted, so conversations stay between you and those you're calling." Given Facebook's scandals and data breaches however these statements should not be trusted or believed. And note the key word "contents." You should assume Facebook will keep records of who you video conference with and when, and that while calls are claimed to be encrypted, they are likely not encrypted against Facebook. An app for Nord VPN would cure that, as Nord VPN has military grade encryption and is not located in the USA, making it not subject to court orders from the USA, etc. I give 3 of 5 stars. Picture, video and audio quality is excellent. Set-up is easy. Lack of enough apps, especially Skype and Nord VPN, is a strong negative. Comparing the Portal Plus from Facebook, the Google Home Hub and Amazon Echo Show (2nd Generation), the Amazon Echo Show appears to be the better product with better value for now.
review_header: Not worth the money and inferior to the Amazon Echo Show - 2nd

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: My husband bought this at full price from Facebook. I hadn't done any research on it and overall, for the price I'd say I'm really disappointed. If you video chat with family members all the time, this is probably a worthwhile investment. Otherwise, wait til they've worked out all the bugs - my feeling is they rushed to get this out for the holiday season when they should have waited and gotten it right. My primary complaint is that it doesn't work great as an Alexa - 20% of the time it just doesn't even respond when I'm standing right there. Sometimes when I play music it will just stop during the middle of a song and still display the album, like it freezes in its Amazon Music capability. Also recently I've set timers that just never go off - I bake a lot, so this is frustrating. I'll get suspicious and be like, "Alexa, how much time is left on my timer?" and it'll say "your timer is currently being delivered" but there is literally no other sound coming out of the portal. Now I just walk into the other room and set timers on our regular Echo. I'm ready to swap them back out because the Echo is way more reliable. Again, the video calls are cool, and the video/sound quality is great, and we made a ton in the first couple of weeks, but most of our family is local so they newness wore off pretty quickly, and I'm left being so disappointed and feeling like we paid way too much.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: The Facebook Portal is an interesting little device that is very solidly built and fairly well designed. It does a very good job when it comes to a couple of key features. It is NOT however replace a smartphone or tablet when it comes to many of the advertised "extra" features. The two tasks that this device excels at is acting as a communications platform for hands-free videoconferencing and acting as an alarm clock/radio. The former uses the Facebook Messenger platform. You can either use voice prompts directly with the device or activate the Amazon Alexa plug-in which gives you some additional voice commands. The videoconferencing feature works extremely well, but obviously only works if the person you are calling is ready and willing to do a video chat with you. The vast majority of people using Messenger only use it for texting or audio calls, so you really have to know someone else using the same platform for video calls for it to be worthwhile. the alarm clock/radio feature is pretty simplistic, but works. The radio basically makes use of the Pandora of Spotify streaming services. There is no option to load your own music via an SD card or choose a different streaming platform. That brings us to the other features of the product, which are basically just a limited number of apps similar to that you can find on an Android device. Most of these apps just let you access specific parts of Facebook or tune-in to a limited number of mass media platforms. By far, the single most useful app that you can download is "Browser", which is a fairly functional web browser that seems to be based on the Android version of Chrome. Using the browser app I was able to login to Amazon and stream movies from their Prime Video collection with no problems. Streaming was flawless and the included speaker made movies easy to hear from across the room. Unfortunately, the audio system does not seem to include an Automatic Gain Control, which makes listening to movies particularly frustrating. The sound will go from being barely audible to far too loud for comfort from one second to another. The device obviously was not designed with multimedia in mind. I do not believe that the audio is even in stereo as it comes from a single speaker. The rest of the apps are pretty much useless. One thing very much worth mentioning here is the lack of ability to easily control the audio unless you are actually standing in front of the device using the touch screen. While you can use Alexa to command the device to increase or decrease volume, it does not do so in increments that are at all practical. The best method of solving this problem would be to include a small remote control. So far, this option does not seem to be available though. I own a number of Android tablets and phones, which begs the question... Why would anyone pay $179 for this device instead of just buying a cheap Android tablet instead? If you are familiar with operating an Android device there really is no reason to choose this product over an Android tablet on which you can already install Messenger, Alexa and many hundreds of more apps. I think that the main market for this device is largely the very old and very young who are not are not very technology savvy. There are quite a few versions of the Amazon Kindle that are less expensive and will do a WHOLE lot more than just act as an oversized alarm clock with messaging features. If you're looking for a way to easily hook your grandparents up to the Internet this might be a good choice given it's extremely simple design. For those of us who have plenty of experience with tablets and smartphones I really can't see any reason to run out and buy this product though.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: Portal is interesting. Facebook is the king of social media, so nearly everybody has a Facebook account and considering other platforms is hard because nowhere else is more of my social circle. Portal is the opposite... almost everybody I know has an Alexa device, and uses the Alexa Show for video conferencing. Sure, I can call people on their Facebook messenger, but most of my friends don't use that on the regular quite yet. If this allowed for full Alexa integration where I could call my family member's Show devices, I think it would justify getting several of these. But this will probably be the only one I keep. After having for a month, I've only used it once, and that person was like, "Why are you calling me like this?" However, I've really struggled with my picture album at work, so I replaced it with this. It's perfect!!! Shows me the photos I want as well as popular photos I've posted or have been tagged in on Facebook. I love seeing all the memories over the last few years. I love it... for that. The video? Not so much.
review_header: Beautiful. Wish it had full Alexa integration, though

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: I'm quite surprised at how much this Portal offers for the price. It's pretty amazing technology that provides incredible sound and recognition features. I got this for my mom who doesn't have Facebook but absolutely loves to see her grandchildren on Facetime, however, Facetime gets difficult for her to use/hold so we thought this was a good option. Let me tell you, it is a game changer. She hasn't set up her own Facebook account yet so I set her up on my account for now. Even though she isn't tech savvy she knows exactly how to work this. It's very simple and easy to use. It also acts as a digital frame so she can see pictures, listen to music and even play games. The sound quality is really great even when she's in the kitchen cooking with her back turned, we can still hear her. This makes a fantastic gift for anyone that you can't see in person all the time and want to keep in touch with them. Highly recommend this device.
review_header: Great way to stay in touch with loved ones

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: My son is stationed in Japan and I bought this to use for our Messenger video calls. It works great. I am so happy to not have to hang onto a cell phone or iPad to talk with him. I‚Äôm hoping the Portal gets released for use in Japan. I would love for him to chat hands free.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: I am a professional A/V Integrator and company owner. So I wanted to demo this myself before recommending it to my clients. I had ours installed within 5 minutes and on our first video chat. Our Portal is connected through the HDMI input of a Denon AVR and the video is shown on a new 75" Sony UHD-TV. We have had a few calls that were pixelated or where the calls were dropped, however I believe that was most likely a reception issue originating from the person(s) we called. Both parties we called live in rural areas or areas that have poor cellular and Ethernet reception. I am quite pleased with the video quality when WiFi strength is good and how effectively the camera adjusts to Zoom and Pan thus accommodating people moving about in the room. If I make a Portal call from my couch the camera zooms onto me and any movements. If my wife enters the room the camera immediately zooms out to get her into frame until she sits next to me on the couch, then the camera zooms in closer to include us both in the video call. Using a Sony Smart TV and enabling HDMI-CEC I can be watching Netflix from the Sony Netflix app and all I have to say is "Hey Portal Call Mom" The Portal responds and begins the call. Once the call begins the Sony TV automatically switches from Netflix to Portal TV. This is perfect for the older generation who are not technically savy. A great way to stay in touch with kids, parents, grandparents and friends afar. We have used the Story Telling feature with our 2 year old grandson who loved the interaction with us. Only Con I have is that it has no hardwired Ethernet connection, only Wi-Fi. When we first installed Portal TV we had Xfinity 300mbps Wi-Fi, last week we upgraded to Google Fiber Gigabit so I again I am certain that any video issues we are experiencing are actually originating from whom we called. It may be they do not have their mobile device camera set at the highest resolution, poor celluar and or Wi Fi reception. I have not tried any of the included streaming apps on the PortalTV as we use the apps from our Sony UHD TV. For the price this a wonderful device, for my many deaf and hearing impaired friends this is AWESOME, as it does have a hand held remote so speaking commands is not necessary.
review_header: Easy set up, great features; perfect for the Deaf and Hearing impaired..

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: This has been a very nice for watching Facebook streamed church services on our big screen tv. I was disappointed to discover that the Portal TV as compared to the other portal devices do not support Zoom. This was not obvious from the Amazon website. If you are trying to have a video chat with someone who does not have WhatsApp or an Apple device, you are out of luck. So far, I have not found anyone who is willing to download Whatsapp so that I can use my portal tv for a video chat! Since Zoom is the most frequently used app for group meetings, this is a major disadvantage. I did email Portal support to ask them when if ever Portal Tv will be able to support Zoom and the answer was that they didn't know. If they don't know, I assume the answer is probably never, though perhaps one day I will be happily surprised. We ended up buying a second Portal device and are fortunate to be able to do so, since our many group streaming opportunities/requirements are on zoom.
review_header: Know that it does not support Zoom

review_text: I want to give 1 star but, Hardware (Camera) is awesome and extra star for the hardware. Facebook portal software needs serious improvement. Tv is accessible to anyone in the house. If you login with your account. anyone in household can use your account, incoming calls, Facebook friends. Software should have option to restrict incoming calls directly going to portal and not phone. It should have option to send the call to portal or use it on phone. Software should have option to sync /stop syncing the latest call has been done from phone (whatsapp/ messenger) It should have option to show only the favorites and restrict to search any other from contact list. Again on keeping privacy, Facebook failed. Portal application crashing so much when you try to chat with support agent.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: My family is spread out all over the country, and so I've been looking for ways to help us feel closer together. Over the years we've tried video calling from smartphones, laptops, iPads, Echo Shows.. you name it. This Christmas I went all-in and bought 3 Portals and NOTHING has been as fun or as easy as these... we love them! - I bought one for the grandparents - PERFECT grandparent gift. Walk up, tap a photo, and you're calling.. the UX is very simple. It's the first device that has been simple enough that my grandparents feel empowered to initiate video calls. - I bought one for my sister with young kids - they LOVE story mode and also all of the built-in effects/costumes. Picture quality seems way clearer than what we used to use (Facebook Messenger on iOS).. and selfishly I love being able to see my nieces and nephews so much more clearly. - I bought one for my parents.. they love it. Finally they can both fit in the screen, unlike when they were always trying to awkwardly hold their iPhones in selfie mode before. I am not affiliated with Facebook in any way, and I'll admit, I wish some other company had invented this product. But this whole thing works so well for my family because it's built on top of Facebook Messenger (which is what we already used to message each other)... and it means we can answer video calls on our phones, laptops, etc. if we're not at home and near the Portal. Small things I wish were better: - It has Alexa but doesn't work with the Ring doorbells - The photo slideshow mode is ok, but didn't surface a lot of gems (personally I wish it drew from Google Photos) - The first day she got it, my nephew went wild and called all of my sisters facebook friends.. she wishes there was a way to "lock it down" to family only - My grandparents often can't hear their portal ringing in a multi-room house (once I had to call their phone to tell them to pick up on their Portal)
review_header: My family absolutely loves this product

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: I bought this for my grandfather just as coronavirus started to become a real concern. I wanted him to be able to video chat with the family when we weren't able to visit him. Unfortunately, his retirement community went on lockdown before I could deliver it. So until I can get it to him, we are using it in our home. I have a 5year old and a 16 month old. Video chatting with them via phone is hard for the people on the other end of the screen. They are ALL OVER THE PLACE and hard to follow. The portal has a nice wide field of vision that keeps them in frame most of the time However the BEST feature is the automatic face detection and camera tracking. It follows the girls all over our living room, keeping them in frame so their grandparents can always see them. It isn't 100% perfect, but it is a huge improvement over not having ng this feature and just trying to follow them with the phone. Surprised - I thought this was a pointless product, but now that I have one, it is the only way I want to video call Fwiw, the Alexa and FB assistant I tegratio s are nice, and the speakers are quite good quality (and powerful). We listen to Pandora, Amazon music, and lots more on here daily. I will probably buy one of these to replace it once I give this one to my grandfather. There are really great for connecting with family.
review_header: Surprisingly great - camera tracking is fantastic

review_text: Being a technophile I think this is better quality than anything Amazon has put out. I purchased 2 portal plus's and while I wish I could call people also on Echo or Skype, the hardware is far better than Echo show (which I also own). I'm not a huge fan of Facebook but the tech is sound and of great quality ( once again comparing to echo show) this is so far a better product than anything currently available and I hope that Google and Amazon take notice. The ability to transfer my call immediately to my phone is on awesome when I leave the room. It's quick and instantaneous and I don't have to think about it. If you dislike Facebook, I can empathize but great tech is great tech and this piece of hardware is fantastic albeit in this day and age I also dont like being locked in to a single communication system but I don't necessarily think that's Facebook fault. I want my hardware independent from any corp and let it speak on it's own merit. We don't live in the 20th century after all.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: My computer software developer son urged me to buy the Portal for my mom who's in an assisted living facility. It's been a lifesaver! I was concerned she wouldn't get the hang of it (she's 103!) but after some practice, she knows how to answer calls, and lights up when she sees our faces on the screen! Mom also loves to watch the slideshow of photos (from my sister's and my Facebook and Instagram pages) that scroll across the screen when she's not talking to us. I'm not nearly as anxious about the thought of another Covid spike in our state, and her assisted living having to shut down visitors again, because I know I'll still be able to "see" her and her apartment, and observe first-hand that all is well for her. It's the second best thing to being there!

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: My siblings and I bought both the Portal TV and Portal+ 15.6" touchscreen for our elderly mom. Repeatedly. The Portal+ was nice because it has Zoom, but Zoom required a fair amount of manual work for every call, and for an elderly person, it was too much. It has a USB C port, which with an HDMI adapter, we hooked it up to a big screen TV for her. Without the adapter, it worked so-so - there were occasional connection issues and whatnot. With the adapter, it worked worse - more connection issues, HDMI-CEC rarely worked (not never, which would've been more acceptable, but rarely which was frustrating knowing it could/should work), green lines on the TV, the TV turning on and off by itself, etc. So we returned it and tried the Portal TV thinking that its sole purpose is to hook up to the TV. Mistake. We tried so many combinations of so many things and we just gave up after a while and returned this one, too. We re-purchased the original touchscreen version with the knowledge that it has big drawbacks, and hoped we just had a couple flukey models. When it works, my mom thoroughly enjoys video calls with her kids all over the country. Instead of working as one would expect (through voice commands dialing any of us using WhatsApp), one of the kids that lives close to her has to drive over more often than not when the device doesn't work and get it going through some random trial and error. Wildly inconvenient, but for her enjoyment... And their tech support... what a joke. I spent a couple months with them - I'd share the issue with the specs of her TV, and they'd reply days later asking what the issue is or what the TV specs are. I'd reply again and not hear back for over a week until after I emailed them again. I'd tell them it works flawlessly only one time right after a factory reset, so they suggest I factory reset it to see if it solves the problem. They'd reply asking for information they already asked for, and at times describing a solve for an issue I never had. And again disappearing for a week until I emailed them again. They asked me to restart the router, which I told them is the retirement complex's router and I don't have access, so they described to me what a router is.
review_header: Good idea, needs a lot of work, and Horrible tech support

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: This device works brilliantly for what it tries to do. Setup was a breeze when linking it to my Facebook account, Alexa integration is great, I love that it acts as a picture frame displaying the latest pics from my Facebook uploads and the video calling via Facebook Messenger is smooth (especially with the camera that pans and zooms as you walk around the room). The filters are also fun and easier to use than on your smartphone! The biggest awkward spot that I found is that I set it up with my account, but my kids are the ones using it most and they've sent goofy video messages to co-workers from my account! There are several other services (Spotify, Pandora, etc.) supported, but I find myself using other devices for those. Overall, the Portal is great, though! As a picture frame and video caller using Facebook Messenger, it can't be beat! Just watch how your kids use it!

review_text: I was so excited about this I bought the prerelease. I was hoping the issue I had with the initial product would be corrected in the coming months but it seems nothing has changed. Pro: Good picture quality Easy setup Cons:. The pan/zoom feature is obnoxious. The AI randomly pans and zooms on occasion when I am not even moving. Either improve the technology or at the very least, give an option to disable it. Connectivity to Facebook messenger is sloppy. Yes, you can search for your contacts and do group video chats but you can't look up or favorite your current Facebook messenger groups to do a video chat. You have to add people to the video call one by one and sometimes finding them via the search function is a challenge. You also cannot save that new group with a unique name for future calls. This seems to be a basic function for a product partnered with Facebook and really needs to be fixed. Pls fix the software and roll out an update. This could be an amazing product with some simple fixes. EDIT: reduced my rating to one star. I would return this if I could. No updates! Still randomly pans and zooms. Difficult to connect to your Facebook groups and the connection drops frequently. I'm back to using my laptop and web cam. I'm so disappointed. Don't waist your money like I did.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: The Facebook Portal plus has a lot of potential and promise but is still in its infancy stages of use for things wider than portal to portal or portal to FB messenger video chats. The Portal plus is easy to set up and not over heavy and can thus be moved from location to location easily, however it does require a WiFi connection and an outlet in order to function. The Facebook Portal Plus has some incredibly amazing technology built in but has not developed enough apps or relationships with outside companies to be as indespensible as it could be one day. For now, the Portal Plus is a realllly cool toy. The camera is high quality and shows incredible imaging. It‚Äôs smart features and ability to follow you while moving around the room is mind blowing. Truly. You can video chat with anyone who has Facebook messenger and is a contact or with another portal user. It does have a very small group of apps that you can download for use with the portal such as YouTube, newsy, iHeartRadio, pandora, Spotify, food network and Facebook (obvi). You can have it show your FB photos but they display ina. Random, nonsensical order. You can watch videos or use it to listen to music IF you have a subscription to the services available but you can not use it to connect to your phone‚Äôs library or playlists as you can with Alexa. The Portal plus responds to verbal commands well but I have found the touchscreen to be supersensitive and thus I am not always able to access what I am looking for. The video and audio quality is excellent and it does connect up with your Alexa does you can use it to respond to questions Or directions asked of Amazon Alexa but not with other amazon services such as prime video or music. Odd. Overall the Portal Plus has A LOT of amazing potential but just is not there yet. IF you are a fan of being an early adopter than this will certainly be an amazing holiday gift however I am hoping that Facebook is looking for feedback and will add the ability to connect to your iPhone to play videos, music or slide shows as well as adding additional apps that can truly take advantage of the incredible technology built into the portal
review_header: A lot of potential but just has not reached its optimal uses as of yet

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: I'm a software engineer by trade. I'm very tech savvy. I have parents who live in a rural area, and so video calling with them is one way we stay close - so that's very important to me. However, it blows my mind in today's day and age that video calling on TVs is not more widespread. Calling on a phone or tablet is fine, but when it comes to wanting to see 2+ people at the same time - those just don't cut it. I looked at several different ways to setup video calling for my parents on a larger screen with a wide angle camera - and Facebook Portal TV was literally the ONLY reasonable option. The next closest was hooking up a laptop and a webcam to a TV, but that is tedious and cumbersome to do frequently. Portal TV fills this product gap, and does so admirably. I read just about every review from the "tech experts" - and almost all of them did not recommend this product simply because it came from Facebook. What a joke. This is an AWESOME product. Those "experts" all judged this product based on name alone, and did their readers a disservice. As someone who could work for Facebook and knows about software, this product appears very safe. The calling is encrypted. You can turn off sending Alexa voice data. The camera tracking software operates locally only. And there are two very easy to use hardware switches to turn off the microphone and video. And you can set pin access to the interface. If you can trust Facebook with a Facebook account, you can trust them with this product. It looks very safe to me if someone just reads the simple instructions. As far as how the product works - I'm only using it for video calling. I do Portal TV to Portal TV with my family. My family has pretty slow internet, and the Portal TV even handled that pretty well. They could always hear and see me pretty well (I have 100 Mbps) and maybe 5% of the time I got fuzzy video or loss of audio and video on their connection (probably 6ish Mbps). That's great. Most things don't do well on my parents internet - and this survived. The camera tracking and panning is excellent - I have seen no issues and played around with it alot. It has comfortably handled 2-4 people walking in and out of the frame. I'm a huge fan. This is an excellent product, and I've recommended it to several people - especially in those covid time. It's not cheap - but I think it's worth it. For my family and I to be able to see each other clearly and comfortably on 50+ in screens is priceless. I'm not a Facebook fanboy. Facebook has totally dropped the ball on a LOT of things in recent years, and their business origins are definitely "complicated". However - I think they did a great job with this product. This is exactly how the experience should be. I'm a very happy Customer.
review_header: Wonderful, and fills a huge product gap in tech

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: I have been told by FBI operatives that the picture clarity of the inside of my house could not get any better. product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: For those who are debating an Alexa device with screen capabilities, whether you will like the Portal or not will depend on what you want to use it for. In taking the smart home plunge, I ended up purchasing 4 Echo Shows (2nd generation) and 2 Facebook Portal+‚Äôs for my home because I wanted both, PA & Drop in function, but also a primo video chat. Here‚Äôs why I have both: The Echo Show (2nd generation) exceeds the Portal + in overall functionality. It provides all of the features of the previous model and more. I wanted some (or all) of my primary devices to sometimes act as a PA & also be able to use the ‚ÄòDrop in‚Äô feature when I am not home. I live in a condo and have an 8wk old puppy coming. Though I work from home, at some point if I need to go on a run or leave for an hour or two, I am still able to access the camera and speak to her if she‚Äôs barking at the front door. For now, Facebook Portal does not have this feature. With the Echo Show there is also no need for an external hub for most of my smart devices because it‚Äôs built right in. I‚Äôm unsure if Portal has this. With the Show, there is also direct access to the internet. Just ask Alexa to play movie trailers, Prime videos, etc. The display is nice, but I would chalk up the video calling and ‚ÄòDrop in‚Äô quality to better than that of my security cameras (also high quality). The Facebook Portal+ display and AI camera technology far exceeds that of any other device I‚Äôve used. I purchased this for the calling feature - which is its‚Äô primary function. During a call, you no longer need to employ being your own camera man during the call - it‚Äôs completely hands-free and smoothly follows you around the room like a movie director. I was impressed by the range at which it accurately followed me and will even follow in the direction of your voice if you happen to step out of the frame. Very limited on other functions though and I expect more are soon to follow within the year once the ‚Äòdata breach‚Äô blah blah stuff calms down a bit. Though the Portal does not support the PA & ‚ÄòDrop in‚Äô functions that the Echo Show has, I can still control all of my smart home devices & groups with ease and employ all of my routines with no problem. If you‚Äôre looking for all-around functionality and more features the Echo Show (2nd) is the way to go. If quality video calling is the priority, then you can‚Äôt beat the Portal+ for now - it far exceeds everything else in that arena.
review_header: Portal+ or Echo Show (2nd) - Good start with hopefully more features coming

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: Bought this so my child could stay in touch and keep in contact with Grandma. The facial recognition feature doesn't catch my daughter and keeps following me around the room. Pretty much worthless when I'm trying to have my daughter and Grandma talk and it keeps following me even though I have picked her for the facial recognition. What a joke

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: For such a slick looking device, this is a real mixed bag. Initial setup was very easy, linking both Facebook and Alexa accounts. The integration for validation was fast and easy. First and foremost, this is a portal - which is generally defined as a door or gate or entry. That's what this is at the end of the day. The Alexa integration is nice, but seems rather singular, maybe others will come later. However, it's definitely a FB Messenger-centric device. It's a pretty large piece of hardware, well packaged and nicely constructed. The screen rotation is super-easy. The first problem was, "where does it go"? As large as it is, it makes one think of an office. Given its ability to work with Alexa and some of the apps on it, we decided the kitchen would be a good place to go - at the edge of a counter where it can stand full height that it is - 18 inches. I am a new user to FB video messaging, so my first focus was making this part of the Alexa ecosystem in the house. The Alexa function is a little substandard - for instance, you can't change the wake word. There are other features that are missing - perhaps this is par for non-Amazon devices. Alexa does work, and there is potential for it to be a more valuable member of the Alexa family with more visual-centric things in the future. At one point, suddenly Alexa wasn't functioning and was acting like a lost network (behavior was the same as our other Echo devices when the network is down). However, network functionality was present on all else (including my other Echo devices). No amount of power cycling or switching networks got it working, and I ended up disconnecting Alexa from it and re-connecting it (which means you have to re-authorize it with Amazon). Not sure how Alexa can lose the "connection" (virtual) and not re-establish it. When Alexa is working, however, it's fine. I wish it was more like a full-up Echo device in terms of all features being supported. Tonight, with two timers set for cooking, it literally failed to deliver. Asking about how much time was left, Alexa responded with "the timer is currently being delivered:". In other words, it was stuck trying to say the timer was done. In fact, both timers had failed - the Alexa app reporting both as with 00:00 remaining. BAD NEWS for a device that you rely on. All of our Echo devices are flawless but the Portal's implementation is not good. Another annoying behavior - I could start listening to iHeart Radio via voice command, but could not make it stop. You can mute it, but not stop it via voice command. A simple "Hey Portal, stop playing" would be nice. I just feel that the portal is very limited - which I suppose is part of being a "portal", but what IS there should be fully voice-supported. Some of the extras, like Food Network, are very light on content. A thirty second view of doing some food item is not much more than showing an idea - this could be a super useful tool in the kitchen (which happens to be where we have it) with some enhancement. While the sound is plenty, it's a little boom-y at the bass end. Most people wouldn't notice it, but I use high-quality speakers with my Echo devices and this just doesn't measure up to those. But, it's completely adequate for messaging and does play decent sound for music. Where this shines is FB video messaging. It's fabulous for that. Our first test was with FB on a phone at the other end of the country, and aside from some small blips of audio interruption, it did great. We don't have fast internet provider and the Portal had no problem on this end. Cell service is iffy at the other end, but it did just find. I see more video glitches and dropouts on our expensive [famous commercial brands] video teleconferenceing than I see on the FB setup. I'm very impressed. I won't go on and on about the value of video, but it's really like being there. We can't see our grandkids as often as we'd like right now, but it's so cool to see them and hear them as they grow - and this totally shortens the interval that we can check in with, compared to transcontinental flight. Awesome. For being essentially a single-tasker, with the side functionality of Alexa, it does well at what it's really designed for, but is disappointing with its Alexa integration. Pricing is pretty steep for this unit, but there's a lot of screen to enjoy and the rotation is a cool feature. However, I think it has a LOT of potential but will be stuck as an only-Facebook device unless there is more development on that part of the function. These days, you need to be widely functional, not focused on just one thing (think smartphones here). But with some increased functionality additions this could really be a hit. As it stands, we want to get one of these (probably the smaller one) for our remote family so we can enjoy full functionality with both ends working the same. But you don't have to have two to enjoy FB messaging on this device, it's a huge step up from the phone-centric video communication with even one end using it.
review_header: Fabulous at FB Messenger video, poor Alexa integration

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: The Portal TV product idea is great - truly ground braking for families. The problem is execution. We bought the Portal TV in order to be closer to the grand parents. Using cell phone based video calling is kind of awkward. You are holding the cell phone in your hand constantly thinking about where the camera is facing. Your'e running around a toddler trying to make sure that she is focused on the picture. The picture on the cell phone is so small that the toddler isnt interested in it for a long time. Portal TV seemed to solve all of these issues. The idea of just lounging on your sofa and seeing the other end in a huge 65 inch picture seemed great. The toddler will see grandma super well. The camera tracking would follow the child in case she is running around. What could be better? The Portal TV does deliver. On the video side. Its a major game changer. I would not go back to cell phone based video calling, unless I absolutely have to. The problem, rather surprisingly, is audio. Portal TV doesnt deliver a full duplex experience where both parties here each others all the time. For whatever reason, Portal TV missed syllables and even whole words. Its difficult to understand what the other end is saying. Disappointing, given that the video part is so good. Not much point doing video calling, if you cant understand what the other end is saying.

I decided that instead of opening my own online voyer cam site, and changing people to watch everything we do here, that i would buy this stuff, let them sell all the info it collects, and then complain about we have no privacy. So while all my personal info gets sold to anyone willing to pay, who will ultimately bear no responsibility to what is done with it or who has access to it - in a few years ill find out that access to all the cams and mics in my home were sold on the dark web so someone could watch me and my family in real time. I will then blame everyone else except the person who bought all the stuff and volunteered to put it in my own house - and completely ignore the 600 million dollar contract the CIA has with Amazon. Cause ya know, theyve both demonstrated how trustworthy they are.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: We bought two for relatives that did not have FB accounts. Here are some of the issues (not with the device but with the service and support. 1) In setting up , had to create FB accounts which meant setting up email or giving our phone numbers for verification purposes. Not a problem, until FB starts to flag it for fraud. While great Fraud detection in concept, not great when now trying to get multiple portal devices up and running with multiple accounts and tried to etup privacy tight. Of course we are setting these up for the Elderly, The whole point it to make video calls easy for them. 2) Once setup configuring the portal seemed easy...everything ok there. 3) After configured, the portals stopped receiving calls.. Calling out was fine. wouldn't receive. So I put my account on the portal...it received fine. Something wrong with the account permissions? Duplicated what I could see from my account to theirs... nope didn't work. Recreated one of the accounts... started working. Then about 10 mins later.. wouldn't receive calls again. At this point I have been trying things for 3 days. Googling, reading the help on Facebook portal. Nothing has flown across the room yet. 4) reached out to support and tried to explain everything on a chat window... not ideal. They gave me all the same advice as the website and google searches. Asked if there was phone support. Lots to get lost with chat. Nope no phone support. Since the problem is not obvious they aren't helpful and tried to send us back to the portal help page. So thank goodness we ordered from Amazon boxed the portals up and sent them back within 2 hrs of lack of support. Going to try the Echo Show...
review_header: Not a good option for those without FB accounts already (elderly) - Support was not helpful

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: I have this facing the living room and dining room table. I frequently call my wife and kids as they are in that area, and the video is amazing. It zooms in on one subject, and follows them if they get up or pans out to capture multiple people in view. It also has all my facebook photos, which makes for a nice screen saver when not in use. Alexa is convenient, but not as functional as an echo device with no ability to drop in on other alexa devices, and limited smart home features, as I can't view my Nest cameras like I can on the Echo Show. It also has a browser, which isn't really convenient for my placement, but others might find it helpful if they put it in a more convenient location. For a video devices, it's 10 stars, since there is nothing else even close to as nice as this, but for a smart hub it's a 3 star, so in my opinion that averages out to a 5 out of 5.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: I have the 1st Gen and decided to buy this upgraded model. I love them both Let me start off by saying if you are not a Facebook user than this may not be the device for you. It's for voice and video chatting with family and friends on Facebook or WhatsApp. It has other apps like Facebook Watch and live. It has Zoom, Bluejeans, Work live and other work services that are not full services. You can't type in the chat. It has Alexa, but it's not a full version. It does not have drop in or call because that is an Amazon feature on the Echos and Dots. You can ask Alexa questions, you can use routines and skills and you can view Alexa enabled cameras and work Alexa enabled smart devices. I have used those features myself on the portal. You can use Alexa to play your Spotify, Iheartradio, Amazon music or Pandora accounts. If you don't have those accounts, Iheartradio is the best free one because as of right now, there is no sign in to use it and it does have advertisment. If you are not a Prime member, you can still use Alexa, just download the Alexa app to your phone, not the Amazon Prime App unless you are a paid Prime member. I have both on my phone because I am a Prime member. The browser is powered by Google and there are some limitations. You can't use the Facebook camera or microphone on websites. You can watch Youtube videos, you can go to the Amazon website, sign in and watch Prime Videos if you are a Prime member. You can watch movies on the Disney+, Hulu, HBOMax and Philo websites, if you pay for those services. I have also done that on the browser. You can't watch Netflix on the browser because Netflix doesn't allow it. It will only play trailers. A Netflix app may be coming soon on the FB Portal. You can use the browser to shop, sign in to email accounts, watch your local live news at their websites, watch Youtube or listen to Youtube music with or without a subscription. Just think of it as an extra TV or non portable laptop. You just can't download or upload to the FB Portal. Now for Non Facebook users. I have another 1st Gen Portal that is no longer connected to Facebook (mainly because I want to use it for entertainment outside) so this option is for you. I used the WhatsApp sign in to activate that Portal. You can only voice and video chat with WhatsApp users (no one really calls me on that app anymore). You cannot use any Facebook features. You can activate Amazon Prime if you are a member and still watch Prime Videos on the browser along with what I mentioned above. You can use Alexa to play your Spotify, Iheartradio, Amazon music or Pandora accounts or use Iheartradio no sign in. Use the browser like I mentioned above and Alexa. I love the FB Portal because it's cheaper than a laptop and I just wanted something to do the bare minimal and I didn't want a tablet either. Using Facebook is a bonus because a lot of my family and friends use messenger or messenger rooms. Love the camera when it follows you or zoom in on others in the room. Overall I am happy with this product and it does everything that I need it do.
review_header: Loved the 1st Gen, love this one too

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: First, I think this is a great idea and an exciting product A simple, turnkey piece of hardware for doing Facetime with some great features. The problem is, it's a product by Facebook who is only really known for their social media application, not for specialized hardware devices. And there's a world of difference between those two worlds. As applications go social media applications are not terribly demanding nor highly sophisticated programs compared to many other applications. Especially when they're written in such a way as to function in the browser world. Specialized hardware applications, on the other hand, must take into account not only the dedicated application that runs on it, but also the hardware and device interfaces that allow it to connect the the outside world. This is the stuff that can become very tricky when trying to make those complex hardware interactions appear to be very simple and bulletproof. Given how easily this type of thing has become in these day of WiFi connected smartphones, computers, laptops, and streaming devices it's easy to overlook that complexity unless you've been in the hardware world for a while. And this is where this device fails. Right out of the box when this device fires up it presents the user with a list of available WiFi connections. You select the one you want and you're asked to enter your password for that network. It sounds simple, but if it fails you don't get much information about why it failed, so troubleshooting it is a problem. The device doesn't come with any information about where to call for support, so unless you know how to do a Google search and find the support site, you're stuck. Once you get in touch with the support line they run you through some very simplistic troubleshooting steps such as a reset of the device and power cycling your WiFi router (which affects anyone or anything else that happens to be using that router at the time). After those few simple steps it gets beyond what the first level of support can provide and they escalate it to the more advanced support group who, in my case, simply emailed me to send it back to Amazon and get a replacement. Given this experience I determined they really weren't ready to be operating in today's more sophisticated hardware environment quite yet and simply sent it back for a refund. The device came with very little in the way of documentation of support information. If you're trying to make it appear to be simple, then it must be bulletproof. Otherwise, it's just frustrating and not worth the time. Especially for the price they're asking for it.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: I will summarize my review upfront like this: if you have family or close friends that you like to keep in touch with through video chat... this device is more than worth the cost. The most practical use is with grandparents and grandchildren. Children may not like looking or talking into a small phone, the portal plus is a much more immersive experience. The revolutionary aspect of the device lies in the camera. The pans and zooms in very naturally, following multiple subjects on the screen at the same time. You really have to experience it to understand. There‚Äôs much more of a feeling that you‚Äôre right there with the other person than other forms of video chat. In my situation, have toddlers and use the portal plus to chat with our parents. Before, we‚Äôd have to chase the kids around with our phones. And echo show seemed like a good idea except it‚Äôs static. Worse than a phone for kids. With the portal plus, we can have it in the living room, and it can literally follow anyone in the living room to the kitchen. It‚Äôs REALLY COOL! Also, I know security is always an issue with these devices. It won‚Äôt satisfy all, but I like that you can easily turn off the mic and camera. It shows you a red light so you know they‚Äôre off. There is also a camera cover. This is more than most devices offer to protect your privacy. I haven‚Äôt tested many of the other features. You can watch YouTube, listen to pandora or Spotify. But I wouldn‚Äôt get this for those features. Again, if you have people you want to communicate with long distance. It‚Äôs a no brainer. Well worth $250. And nothing else on the market comes close.
review_header: Niche device.. but REVOLUTIONARY for what it offers

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: The biggest hurdle for this unit to overcome is the Facebook name, and I must admit it‚Äôs a big hurtle at that. It has safety and sharing features built in, but no company is under scrutiny like Facebook, and that can‚Äôt be overlooked. For those concerned, there‚Äôs a lens cover included (but it‚Äôs not attached so could be lost, and is a bit cheap looking on an otherwise beautiful unit) and easy mute function. Blocking both film and audio is as simple as a tap in the middle of the top of the unit which stops audio and video communication. Features otherwise can be broken down into video calling, Alexa controls, and sound quality. With regard to video calling, this is where the portal most excels, but yet is most limited. The ability for the portal camera to zoom and track about the room is simply uncanny. You feel like you‚Äôre on a TV show, as the camera simply figures out the most appropriate look, giving an amazing feeling of connection with whom you‚Äôre calling. The large widescreen can be switched to vertical or horizontal orientation so the picture always fills the screen. There is an assortment of visual Add-ons during voice calls (available currently on Facebook messenger if you want to give them a test drive) such as turning yourself into a dragon, or a dancing strawberry, or the fun ability to read fairytale type book to the person on the other side. Our kids adored this. But speaking of kids, if this is in their reach, they are going to have access to your Facebook contacts, which could lead to some embarrassing accidental calls. With this quality comes the downside, as it can only connect with Facebook messenger users. With Facebook‚Äòs recent negative press and data breaches, it‚Äôs a hard sell to get your friends to reconnect with Facebook. Amazon is getting a firm foothold with their echo show and its ability for face-to-face calling, and this system‚Äôs lack of ability to contact those people has a huge detractor. Let me be clear, this unit can only be used to call via Facebook messenger. As far as its Alexa qualities, it‚Äôs nearly perfect. You use the portal commands (‚Äúhey Portal!‚Äù) for video calling, but most other features are run through Alexa commands. NOTE: You‚Äôll need to download the Alexa app for full functionality! It was relatively easy to set this up and within a few hours I was controlling my lights with voice commands. Alexa‚Äôs ability for downloadable games such as 20 questions or jeopardy were easily filtered and able to be used. I did have a few issues for the first few days with getting Alexa to hear my commands, but it seemed to adapt and now listens without concerns. Lastly, the sound quality is pretty stellar. It has solid base, akin to an Amazon echo, or even a Sonos speaker (Sonos is the easy leader in sound quality of the group, make no mistake). Listening to Amazon music is a joy but Spotify requires a premium membership for use. Most disappointingly, you cannot use Bluetooth speakers as extensions for multi room audio, but only Bluetooth connection to a single unit at a time which disables the Portal‚Äôs own speaker. I feel this is a huge detractor, and worthy of a loss of a ‚Äústar‚Äù on this alone. Overall, if you‚Äôre using this to call another portal, or someone on Facebook messenger, it‚Äôs an unbelievable piece of equipment. It‚Äôs ability to follow during phone calls, and it‚Äôs overall quality, blows the echo out of the water. It has the added advantage of many Alexa uses, but it, surely by design, doesn‚Äôt call other Echo Show units which is a huge hindrance. If you can get past the Facebook association, or if you are an active Facebook messenger user, this is a dream piece of technology which will be welcome in your home. If you don‚Äôt use Facebook and you don‚Äôt have many messenger contacts, this unit‚Äôs superior camera quality, beautiful bass, and immaculate screen might be wasted on you. Pros: Video calling quality is just beautiful, and the tracking feature gives an unbelievable sense of ‚Äúbeing there‚Äù Beautiful styling Cons: Must log in with Facebook No multiroom Bluetooth speaker support I hope this review was helpful. If so, let me know by clicking ‚Äúhelpful‚Äù below!
review_header: An in-depth look at Facebook's new Portal+; my favorite (and least favorite) features

review_text: Pros: simple to set up and audio/video quality is amazing. Camera motion is really smooth and reliable and overall a great device that is optimized for video chat. Nails the call grandparents scenario for my kids. Cons: has to be plugged in. There's no battery. This is annoying. It's 2020 put a battery in it. You'd think this is obvious but it makes the device super lame that it has to be plugged in. UX can be clunky at times. We all naturally have a lot of Facebook friends but I don't want my son to accidentally dial a friend I haven't talked to in 10 years. The angle of the stand is a little off. When on a table it seems to point the camera towards ceiling more than we would prefer. So you end up being in the bottom half of the frame not the whole thing.
review_header: Almost perfect but a few misses. Still great device to call grandma

review_text: This was purchased for my 90 year old Mother in Law. She lives in a remote location and is totally technology lacking (no smart phone, no computer, no tablet, limited cell coverage, etc.). We wanted some way to better connect to her, particularly with COVID and travel restrictions. Additionally she lives in an area that gets sever winter weather that restricts travel. Portal is a game changer! All she has to do is say "Portal call "name"" and Portal initiates a video call to one of her daughters or grandchildren. If a call comes in its as easy as "Portal answer." This is the only device that I can imagine that would allows this non- tech savvy 90 year old to be able to enjoy face to face calls. Great job Facebook and the Portal Team!

review_text: Very limited in its use. I dont use Facebook/Messenger/Workplace. I bought this purely because I saw it supported whatsapp and zoom calling and I wanted to use it with a spare TV I had. To my disappointment this device does NOT support Zoom app at all. Facebook‚Äôs portal site is obscure and does not clearly state that not all apps are supported on all portal devices. I cannot understand the rationale why Facebook would not support Zoom on the portal TV. Portal TV is the only device where it makes sense to at least support such communication apps. Most folks use Zoom for work video calls, why would anyone bother buying a $100+ 4 inch screen device to use for zoom/whatsapp/messenger when they already have the same apps on their phones and tablets. Great concept but poor app support will kill this product. I will be returning mine. I did try whatsapp video call and it was pretty good in terms of voice and video quality.

review_text: The set up and usage has been full of issues. Their customer service is good. They call you within minutes. Bu the machine rejected our home wifi when every other device was working. We had to change the router password and reset it even though all of our phones and home computers where working. YOU CAN NOT CALL THIS DEVICE FROM A COMPUTER. Only from phones, tablets or other portals. Very sad. The device when it works is easy to use even for my 85 year old father who we bought it for. Yet the difficulty of set up and the lack of compatibility with computers is dis heartening.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: If you are thinking about the Portal or Portal Plus, here is my experience. I started out with just the Portal. It had clear resolution and a good camera already. But I used it so much that I decided to upgrade to Portal Plus. It was well worth it only because I use it everyday to video call. Beyond that, it‚Äôs like a regular tablet with not many apps. SOUND The sound is MUCH better on the Portal Plus. It provides deeper bass. The regular Portal still has good sound too. But if you plan to use it for music, the Portal Plus is what I recommend as it is just one tier below an Echo in sound quality. Portal Plus wins by a large margin. VIDEO The Portal Plus provides a more clear picture while video calling. It almost feels as if the other person is right there. Portal Plus wins by a good margin (1080p vs 720p). CAMERA The camera is slightly bigger on the Portal Plus. From the other side of video calling, the person said it was maybe slightly better but hardly noticeable. Portal Plus barely wins. SCREEN SIZE Screen size on the Portal Plus is obviously bigger, however, it‚Äôs not ‚Äòenormously‚Äô bigger. The regular Portal will deliver enough for a good video calling experience. Portal Plus wins by a decent margin. OVERALL Get the Portal Plus over the Portal only if you plan to use it frequently. The price point is not worth it, otherwise.

review_text: This thing is amazing. It's perfect for us in a kitchen, where you would move around while talking. The camera follows you and focuses on you, wherever you are. While it's not otherwise engaged, it displays your Facebook photo album. It also supports multiple Facebook accounts (but not multiple alexa accounts), so it can mix pictures from your partner's account in the slideshow. The mic is excellent. Alexa can hear me from clear in the other room, just like a person would. I can say "alexa, play cbs news," and the live stream comes right up. It's big enough that I use it as a mini television to watch the news while cooking. LOVE IT!

Yesterday we just found out that with her Kindle and my Portal, we can make all kinds of silly illusions, like changing into a dragon or putting on a Santa beard. product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: Review after two months of use: It's an excellent device and we've been using it a lot to video chat with family and friends. The best thing is the sounds. I can hear the other side loud and clear through my TV's speaker and they can hear me as well even when I'm far from the device. My TV has hdmi-cec capability and it was able to switch to the correct hdmi input using the tv remote's home button so that's good. I do wish I could manually zoom the camera. Maybe that'll come in a future update. One of my favorite features is the ability to leave a 30 second voice message to any of my contacts without dialing. I wish they would extend that to a minute or two though. We use this to send a short personal greeting to families and friends during holidays and we can even use effects while we're at it. Lastly, if you're choosing among the Portal lineups, know that Portal TV so far has always been last to get new Portal features. I'm a member of the Facebook group and we like comparing notes there. While other Portals has the ability to change their backgrounds into those cool Zoom-like virtual backgrounds, this feature is not available yet to Portal TV as of July 1, 2020. I would still choose Portal TV though coz I like seeing my contacts in the big screen. I hope Facebook keeps improving this as it is definitely a winner.
review_header: No manual zoom and no virtual backgrounds yet; otherwise excellent

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: After everything that is happening with Facebook in the news, to say we were reluctant at first to use this was an understatement. However, with the benefit of helping my homesick wife talk with her family in a convenient package kinda outweighed everything. The Portal Plus, is a great piece of tech, marred by sub-par software implementation. The main feature of the Portal Plus is video calling, it is center-stage. Performance is phenomenal and the ability for the camera to track your movement makes conversations feel dynamic. Most of my family and friends use facebook, so I am able to interact with them easily, and that is where the Portal Plus shines. Besides video calling, it features not much else. A handful of apps like Cooking and Spotify exist. Lacking any true developer backing leaves the Portal Plus feeling underutilized and a rush to market. Alexa is enabled but doesn't include the abilities of the Echo Show even though it features a beautiful screen. Granted the Portal Plus accomplishes its main goal gloriously, video calling, I believe it could be much more. Wonder what the future has in store for the Portal Plus. For now, we are happy with the video quality and ease of use but disappointed with the total features.

product_title: Facebook Portal - Smart Video Calling 10‚Äù Touch Screen Display with Alexa - Black
review_text: The Video conferencing is the only reason I'm giving this one star otherwise this doesn't even worth the one star, I'm upset of it because it lacks a lot of a very basic functionalities that are available on similar products, I use the echo show 2 all the time, and this device can't do 90% of what the echo show 2 can do. How could it be better? well the number one thing that I need to be able to use it is keyboard/mouse support. You can browse the web on this device, but with the touch screen it's very annoying with the onscreen keyboard. Apps, very limited apps, not even a Facebook app, come on! It's totally locked, so you can't add apps from other sources. You can't do anything with the Camera, it's only for calling someone on your Facebook friends list who also have to be on a mobile device or another portal, you can't communicate with a guy using Facebook from a laptop for example. You can't stream, take a picture, or use it as a mirror, because there's not camera app even. and the price, I got it on discount and I'd kill my self if I've bought it retail because it totally doesn't worth it. So again if you only want to video call someone who happen to have a portal, then this might be a good device for you if you intended to do a lot of video calls other wise don't bother.
